questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in cell injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Calcium:

  • Calcium ions play a significant role in cell injury.
  • Increased intracellular calcium levels can trigger several damaging processes within the cell.
  • Excessive calcium influx into the cell can lead to mitochondrial dysfunction, activation of enzymes that degrade cellular components, and disruption of cell membrane integrity.
  • These processes can ultimately result in cell death.

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is a disorder associated with delusion?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Thought

  • Delusions are fixed, incorrect beliefs that persist despite contradicting evidence. They frequently involve ideas that are absurd, illogical, or impossible. Delusional people could have strong convictions about topics others consider illogical or untrue.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Affect refers to emotions and mood. It is a short-term or cross-sectional emotional state. It may include disorders like depression and bipolar disorder.

Option C. Perception refers to the interpretation of sensory information. It may include disorders like illusion and hallucination.

Option D. Memory involves the encoding, storage, and retrieval of information. It may include disorders like Alzheimer’s disease and dementia.

questions.text: Which of the following is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sickle cell anemia: Sickle cell is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

Incorrect Options - A, C, and D are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

questions.text: Liquefactive necrosis is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Brain:

  • Liquefactive necrosis is characterized by the dissolution of affected cells, resulting in a liquid, viscous appearance.
  • It typically occurs in organs with abundant enzyme activity and limited structural support, such as the brain.
  • In the brain, this form of necrosis can be observed in cases of cerebral infarction or abscess formation.
  • The liquefied material is often composed of dead cells, tissue debris, and inflammatory cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Heart: The most common type of cell death seen in the heart is coagulative necrosis.

Option C - Lungs: The lungs are prone to different types of necrosis, including coagulative necrosis in response to infarction and caseous necrosis in certain infections like tuberculosis.

Option D - Kidney: Renal tissue is susceptible to ischemic injury, leading to coagulative necrosis in most cases.

questions.text: What is the probable medical condition for a 25-year-old male who experienced a road traffic accident and is now experiencing anxiety about driving and going to the site of the incident for a period of 6 weeks? He is also having recurring memories of the accident and struggles with attending work.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Post-traumatic stress disorder:

  • Based on the provided information, the likely diagnosis for the individual is Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). PTSD is a mental health condition that can develop after experiencing or witnessing a traumatic event. The symptoms described, such as fear of driving, experiencing flashbacks of the accident, and difficulty going to work, are consistent with the diagnostic criteria for PTSD. It is important for the individual to seek professional help for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute Stress Disorder: Is characterised by symptoms that are similar to PTSD but last for 3 days to 1 month. The case is less likely to have ASD because the symptoms have lasted 6 weeks.

Option C - Panic disorder: Is distinguished by repeated panic attacks and concern about future attacks. While the individual may be anxious due to the accident, the symptoms stated do not match the essential characteristics of panic disorder.

Option D - Major Depressive Disorder: Involves symptoms like persistent sadness, loss of interest, and changes in appetite or sleep patterns. In the given case, the primary focus is on the trauma-related symptoms (flashbacks, avoidance, etc.) rather than the main symptoms of MDD.

questions.text: The cause of edema in nephrotic syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Decreased colloid osmotic pressure:

  • In nephrotic syndrome, the kidneys lose large amounts of protein, particularly albumin, through the urine.
  • Since albumin helps maintain colloid osmotic pressure in the blood vessels, decreased levels of albumin result in decreased colloid osmotic pressure. Osmotic pressure is a retaining force.
  • This reduction in colloid osmotic pressure leads to fluid shifting from the blood vessels into the surrounding tissues, causing edema.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Von Willebrand disease: Von Willebrand disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Incorrect Options - B, C, and D are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

questions.text: Which mineral deficiency can potentially cause the condition depicted in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Zinc – Treatment – 30-50 mg elemental zinc

The condition is known as Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, it is a condition where due to a deficiency of zinc in the body of the children leads to allergic skin lesions. The treatment for this is 30-50 mg of elemental zinc to be given to the baby.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option B: iron - Generally in the case of iron deficiency leading to an anemia component in the patient, the skin appears pale or there may be tiny red or purple dots on the skin in a case of aplastic anemia and even pruritus ( itchy skin) may be present which when scratched gives a red, swollen skin.

Option C: Calcium - Whereas in the case of calcium deficiency for a long time may lead to brittle nails along with dry and cracked skin. Apart from skin, there may be a coarse texture of the hair and even psoriasis, alopecia, and eczema.

Option D: vitamin A - Apart from delayed growth and development in a child and night blindness due to a deficiency of vitamin A components, dry, scaly, and itchy skin also occurs. In females, there may be problems associated with fertility and conception.

questions.text: Which of the following can be given to a celiac disease patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Quinoa:

  • Quinoa is a gluten-free grain and can be safely consumed by individuals with celiac disease.
  • Quinoa does not contain gluten and is considered a suitable alternative for people following a gluten-free diet.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D should be avoided by individuals with celiac disease.

questions.text: What is the most likely karyotype for a 16-year-old girl who presents with short stature, primary amenorrhea, and widely spaced nipples?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - 45, XO

  • The patient’s presentation with short stature, primary amenorrhea, and widely spaced nipples is suggestive of Turner syndrome.
  • The karyotype of this patient is 45, XO.

Incorrect Options - B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is present in celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Options D - All of the above:

  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition characterized by an immune reaction to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.
  • When gluten is ingested by individuals with celiac disease, it triggers an immune response that leads to damage in the small intestine.
  • Antibodies play a crucial role in the diagnosis of celiac disease.
    • Tissue transglutaminase IgA (tTG IgA)
    • Endomysial IgA
    • Reticulin IgA

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Koplik spots are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Measles:

  • Koplik's spots are small, white spots with a bluish-white center and red halo that appear on the buccal mucosa and are pathognomonic for measles.

Incorrect Options:

Koplik’s spots are not seen in options A, C, and D.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a person experiencing a reduced sense of enjoyment in activities that they previously found pleasurable?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: Anhedonia

  • Anhedonia refers to the decreased ability to experience pleasure or a lack of interest in activities that were previously enjoyable. It is a symptom commonly associated with various mental health conditions, particularly depressive disorders such as major depressive disorder (MDD). Other symptoms of depression may also be present alongside anhedonia, such as changes in appetite, sleep disturbances, low mood, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating.
  • There are two types of anhedonia:
    1. Social anhedonia: This refers to a reduced ability to experience pleasure from social interactions or relationships. People with social anhedonia may find it difficult to engage in and enjoy social activities, leading to feelings of isolation and disconnection.
    2. Physical or sensory anhedonia: This refers to a diminished pleasure response to sensory stimuli, such as taste, touch, or other physical sensations. Individuals may have difficulty deriving pleasure from activities such as eating delicious food, engaging in sexual experiences, or experiencing the enjoyment of touch or warmth.
  • Treatment for anhedonia often involves a combination of psychotherapy and medication. Psychotherapeutic approaches such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and behavioral activation can help individuals identify and modify negative thought patterns and engage in pleasurable activities. Antidepressant medications, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or other classes of antidepressants, may also be prescribed to address anhedonia as part of overall symptom management.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Tangentiality is a formal thought disorder where the person responds to questions with irrelevant details that never reach a goal.

Option C. Alexithymia is difficulty in identifying and expressing emotions.

Option D. Asociality includes a lack of interest or motivation to engage in social interactions.

questions.text: Which is the most specific antibody in systemic sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anti-topoisomerase:

  • Anti-topoisomerase (Anti-Scl-70) antibodies are highly specific for systemic sclerosis, particularly its diffuse cutaneous subtype.
  • These antibodies target an enzyme called topoisomerase I, which is involved in DNA replication and repair.
  • The presence of anti-topoisomerase antibodies is strongly associated with skin involvement and internal organ complications in systemic sclerosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anti-DNA:

  • Anti-DNA antibodies are typically associated with autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) rather than systemic sclerosis.
  • While anti-DNA antibodies may be present in some cases of systemic sclerosis, they are not considered specific to the disease.

Option C - ANA:

  • ANA (antinuclear antibodies) is a general term for antibodies that target components within the cell nucleus.
  • While ANA can be detected in various autoimmune diseases, including systemic sclerosis, it is not specific to the condition.
  • ANA testing is often used as a screening tool to indicate the presence of an autoimmune process, but it does not provide a definitive diagnosis on its own.

Option D - Anti-Ro:

  • Anti-Ro (SS-A) antibodies are associated with various autoimmune conditions, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and Sjögren's syndrome.
  • While they may occasionally be detected in systemic sclerosis, they are not specific to the disease.

questions.text: What is the rare and hazardous complication associated with Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Measles:

  • Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis is a rare fatal, severe, long-standing complication of measles.
  • It is a progressive neurological disorder that affects the central nervous system.
  • It typically develops 7-13 years after primary measles infection.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What could be the probable diagnosis for a woman who has been brought to the psychiatrist 5 weeks post-delivery, displaying symptoms of fearfulness, irritability, and suicidal ideation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Postpartum depression:

  • Based on the symptoms described, the likely diagnosis for the female in question is Postpartum depression (PPD). Postpartum depression is a mood disorder that occurs after childbirth, typically within the first few weeks to months.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Postpartum blues/Baby blues result from psychological factors such as the emotional stress of childbirth and the feelings of added responsibility. It gets resolved within 7-10 days of delivery.

Option B - Post-partum psychosis: Tearfulness, sleeplessness, and even delusions and hallucinations (the baby is dead, she didn't give birth) are all symptoms of postpartum psychosis.

Option D - Panic disorder: Panic disorder is a different condition characterised by continuous episodes of panic attacks.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common brain tumor seen in children?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Medulloblastoma:

  • Medulloblastoma is the most common brain tumors seen in children.
  • It typically occurs in the cerebellum, which is the part of the brain responsible for coordination and balance.
  • Medulloblastomas are fast-growing tumors that often present with symptoms such as headaches, vomiting, unsteadiness, and problems with motor coordination.
  • Treatment typically involves a combination of surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Incorrect options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: How long is the protection provided by the Yellow fever vaccine considered valid for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Life long:

  • Yellow fever vaccine provides lifelong protection against yellow fever.

Incorrect options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 21-year-old female who avoids using elevators due to fear and always opts for stairs instead?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Specific phobia:

  • Specific phobias involve strong, persistent, and irrational fear of an object or situation. The phobia of elevators or lifts given in the question is a situational phobia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Social Phobia: Involves intense fear and anxiety in social situations. It is also known as a social anxiety disorder. Individuals with this phobia usually fear embarrassment or humiliation in front of others.

Option B - Agoraphobia: Individuals with Agoraphobia have the fear of places which are difficult to escape. For example, fear of open spaces, traveling alone, crowded places, or public transport.

Option D - Panic disorder: Involves recurring panic attacks, but the fear here is specifically related to elevators rather than panic attacks.

questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding should be continued for a minimum of how many months?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: 6 months:

  • Breastfeeding is exclusively recommended for the first 6 months of life.
  • It ensures child health and higher survival rates.

Incorrect options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Football player gets blow to the outer knee during match. Which structure is most commonly associated with this type of injury?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B:

  • The MCL is a ligament located on the inner side of the knee joint that helps stabilize the knee against excessive sideways or valgus stress. It connects the femur (thigh bone) to the tibia (shin bone) and plays a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of the knee joint.
  • When the knee undergoes a forceful impact from the outer side, such as a blow to the outer knee during sports like football, it can result in a valgus stress on the knee. This valgus force can cause the MCL to stretch or tear, resulting in an MCL injury.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL): While the ACL is another important ligament in the knee, it is not directly associated with MCL injuries. The ACL is located inside the knee joint and is responsible for controlling rotational and anterior translation of the tibia in relation to the femur.

Option C. Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL): The PCL is also an internal ligament of the knee, but it is not commonly associated with MCL injuries. The PCL helps stabilize the knee against posterior translation of the tibia in relation to the femur.

Option D. Lateral meniscus: The lateral meniscus is the counterpart of the medial meniscus and is located on the outer side of the knee joint. It is not directly associated with MCL injuries. However, it can be injured independently or in conjunction with other knee injuries.

questions.text: A Clinician asks a patient “how is your mood”. Patient replies by saying “ It is going up & down”. What is the phenomenon seen here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tangentiality

  • Tangentiality is when a patient responds to a question in a way that is obliquely related or completely unrelated to the question and never reaches the point.

  • In this case, the doctor asks about mood, and the patient gives a vague, non-specific response: “It is going up and down,” which does not clearly describe the mood but instead skirts the topic in a generalized manner.

Formal Thought Disorders

Term Description
Tangentiality The patient gives an oblique or irrelevant answer and never reaches the point.
Derailment Sudden shifting of ideas with no logical connection between them.
Clang association Speech based on sound (rhyming/punning) rather than logical connections.
Neologism Newly invented words with idiosyncratic meaning.

 

Derailment (Option A):
Incorrect because the response “It is going up and down” is not a sudden topic shift—it remains vaguely on topic but is non-specific.

Clang association (Option C):
Incorrect because there is no evidence of rhyming or sound-based connections driving the speech.

Neologism (Option D):
Incorrect because no new or made-up words were used in the sentence.

questions.text: Avascular necrosis of the femur head is due to which of the following artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Medial Circumflex Femoral Artery:

  • Medial Circumflex Femoral Artery (MCFA): The MCFA is a branch of the deep femoral artery and provides the primary blood supply to the femoral head. Disruption or occlusion of this artery can lead to compromised blood flow to the femoral head, resulting in avascular necrosis.
  • The diagnosis and management of avascular necrosis of the femoral head typically involve a combination of clinical evaluation, imaging studies (such as X-rays, MRI, or bone scans), and treatment options ranging from conservative measures to surgical interventions, depending on the severity and stage of the condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lateral Circumflex Femoral Artery (LCFA): The LCFA is also a branch of the deep femoral artery, but it primarily supplies blood to the muscles around the hip joint and does not directly supply the femoral head.

Option C - Obturator Artery: The obturator artery primarily supplies blood to the muscles of the medial thigh and does not directly supply the femoral head.

Option D: None of the above

questions.text: What should be the course of action for the newborn if the mother, who is a first-time pregnant woman, arrives at the hospital at 37 weeks of pregnancy with no prior antenatal check-ups and is currently in labor, while also testing positive for Hepatitis B?

choices.text: First immunoglobulin, then Hep B vaccine after 1 month

questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B. Hep B vaccine + immunoglobulin

The combination of the Hepatitis B vaccine and immunoglobulin (HBIG) is the preferred management given to the neonate. It gives both immediate and long-term protection against Hepatitis B to the baby. It protects the neonate from the vertical transmission of the virus. The vaccine stimulates the baby's immune system to produce antibodies against the virus, while the immunoglobulin provides immediate passive immunity.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Hep B Vaccine only is insufficient for managing a neonate born to a Hepatitis B positive mother.

Option C. It is essential to give the Hepatitis B vaccine and immunoglobulin to the neonate shortly after birth. Delaying the vaccine for a month would not provide immediate protection.

Option D. Hepatitis B immunoglobulin is necessary. But it should be administered with the Hepatitis B vaccine for better management.

questions.text: Which one of the options pertains to McNaughten's rule?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: IPC 84

  • Mc Naughten's rule is a legal standard for determining insanity in criminal cases. IPC 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) addresses the defence of insanity in criminal cases.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: IPC 85: An act of a person rendered incapable of judgement due to intoxication committed against his will.

Option C: IPC 86: Offence committed by an intoxicated person that requires specific knowledge or intent.

Option D: IPC 87: Act that was done with permission but wasn't done with the intention of causing death or serious harm.

questions.text: Identifying finding seen in TB knee is
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option: A

Tuberculosis of the knee, also known as tuberculous arthritis or Pott's disease of the knee, is a form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis that affects the knee joint. In this condition, the tuberculosis bacteria infect the synovial lining of the knee joint, leading to inflammation, destruction of joint structures, and subsequent reduction of the joint space.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Increase in joint space: Tuberculosis of the knee typically leads to destruction and narrowing of the joint space rather than an increase. This is due to the destructive nature of the infection, which can erode the articular cartilage and other joint structures.

Option C. Degeneration of cartilage: While the destruction of joint structures, including cartilage, is a characteristic feature of tuberculosis of the knee, it does not manifest as degeneration in the sense of wear-and-tear or age-related changes. Rather, it is the result of the direct effects of the tuberculosis infection on the joint.

Option D. none of the above this option is incorrect

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a child who has abdominal pain, haematuria, and palpable purpura over the leg, as depicted in the image, with IgA deposition observed on biopsy of the skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Correct option: Option B. HSP

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a condition associated with inflammation of blood vessels.
  • The causes of HSP are unknown.
  • HSP affects the small blood vessels of the body leading to rash, which is also known as purpura.
  • Following are the symptoms of HSP
  • a skin rash, which appears like small bruises or small reddish-purple spots – it is usually seen on the legs and around the elbows and buttocks.
  • Swelling of the feet and hands, and sometimes swelling of the scrotum in males.
  • Pain in the joints, mostly of knees and ankles, stomachache, blood in the faeces or urine.

Incorrect options:

Option A: IgA nephropathy is present with hematuria 1 to 3 days after the onset of upper respiratory tract infection. IgA nephropathy is also known as Berger disease.

Option C: RPGN is a Rapid loss of Renal function following GN presents with Oliguria/Anuria, Raised renal function test, and Bleeding manifestations.

Option D: PSGN, i.e., post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, occurs 1 to 2 weeks after the onset of upper respiratory tract infection, and it is also associated with haematuria.

questions.text: Most potent opioid is?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Fentanyl

  • An opioid with great potency is fentanyl. Fentanyl and sufentanil, two highly potent opioids, have been used as adjuncts to general anesthetics.
  • They have also been combined with BZDs (in large doses) to achieve global anesthesia. A strong synthetic opioid analgesic with a short half-life of 30 to 50 minutes is fentanyl.
  • Along with other IV anesthetics, short-acting fentanyl-like derivatives like alfentanil and remifentanil have been used to induce anesthesia. Low dosages of them can be applied epidurally to provide postoperative analgesia. Larger doses of powerful opioids, such as fentanyl, can cause thoracic wall stiffness, obstructing mechanical ventilation.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Morphine is a potent opioid analgesic medication commonly used for the management of severe pain.Morphine exerts its pharmacological effects by binding to opioid receptors in the central nervous system (CNS), particularly the mu-opioid receptors.Activation of mu-opioid receptors inhibits the release of various neurotransmitters, such as substance P, resulting in a decreased transmission of pain signals.Additionally, morphine acts on other opioid receptors, including kappa and delta receptors, which contribute to its analgesic and other effects.

Option C: Pentazocine: it is a synthetic opioid analgesic that is commonly used for the management of moderate to severe pain. It exhibits mixed opioid receptor activity, acting as an agonist at kappa-opioid receptors and as a partial agonist at mu-opioid receptors.

Option D : Pethidine- Pethidine, also known as meperidine, is a synthetic opioid analgesic used for the treatment of moderate to severe pain. It acts as a mu-opioid receptor agonist, similar to morphine.

questions.text: Which is not a contraindication for OPV?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B. Diarrhoea

  • Diarrhea mostly recurs in children, and it usually doesn't possess a specific risk; hence it is not a contraindication for OPV. It is usually recommended that children continue their routine vaccination schedule for OPV unless they are severely ill.

Incorrect options:

Option A is Incorrect because for leukemia it is contraindicated to give OPV vaccine as it can alter the immune responses or even increase the risk of complications.

Option C is Incorrect because, for Malignancy, it is contraindicated to give OPV vaccine as it can alter the immune responses or even increase the risk of complications.

Option D is Incorrect because, for Immunocompromised, it is contraindicated to give OPV vaccine as it can alter the immune responses or even increase the risk of complications.

questions.text: 1st line treatment for acne and comedones should be:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Topical retinoids:

  • Being a chronic inflammatory disease of pilosebaceous units, acne is characterized by the formation of comedones, erythematous papules, and pustules. Generally, the first-line treatment for acne is topical retinoids as they are very much effective against comedones and other inflammatory acne.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Topical steroids: The treatment of acne with topical steroids is highly contraindicated as steroids aggravate the acne in many cases. Also in cases of children, it is generally not prescribed.

Option B - Topical antibiotics: Though antibiotics are used in the treatment of acne, compared to the topical retinoids used in the 1st line management of acne comedones these topical antibiotics are used up, particularly in cases involving inflammatory acne.

Option D - Benzoyl peroxide: The treatment with benzoyl peroxide is not at all applicable for sensitive skin as it gets dried more easily and thus leads to skin irritation.

questions.text: Which mineral is associated with the functioning of carbonic anhydrase?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Zinc:

Zinc is an essential mineral that plays a crucial role in the activity of carbonic anhydrase, an enzyme involved in the conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) to carbonic acid (H2CO3) in various tissues and cells of the body.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Iron: Iron is not directly linked to the activity of carbonic anhydrase. It primarily functions in oxygen transport and storage as a component of hemoglobin in red blood cells.

Option C - Calcium: While calcium plays important roles in various physiological processes such as bone health, muscle contraction, and nerve function, it is not directly associated with carbonic anhydrase activity.

Option D - Potassium: Similar to calcium, potassium is not directly linked to the activity of carbonic anhydrase. Potassium is an essential mineral involved in maintaining proper cell function, nerve transmission, and fluid balance.

questions.text: Unilateral renal agenesis in an infant is linked with:
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Single umbilical artery:

Unilateral renal agenesis:

  • Absent kidney development on one side
  • Secondary to defect of wolﬃan duct / ureteric bud / metanephric blastema
  • Increased incidence in neonates with single umbilical artery

Incorrect Options - B, C, and D are not linked to unilateral renal agenesis in an infant.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of allopurinol is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Xanthine oxidase inhibition:

  • Allopurinol is a medication primarily used for the management of gout and certain types of kidney stones.

Mechanism of Action

  • Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor. It inhibits the enzyme xanthine oxidase, which is responsible for the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and then to uric acid.

  • By inhibiting xanthine oxidase, allopurinol reduces the production of uric acid, thereby lowering the uric acid levels in the blood and urine.

Incorrect Options:

Options B - Recombinant uricase: Recombinant uricase, also known as pegloticase, is a medication used for the treatment of chronic gout in adults who have not responded adequately to other therapies. Uricase catalyzes the conversion of uric acid, a byproduct of purine metabolism, into allantoin, a compound that is more soluble and can be easily eliminated by the kidneys. By converting uric acid to allantoin, pegloticase reduces the serum uric acid levels and helps dissolve urate crystals in tissues.

Option C - Increase uric acid excretion: Uricosuric agents work by inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid in the renal tubules, thereby increasing its elimination in the urine. Eg Probenecid, Benzbromarone and Lesinurad.

Option D - Decrease chemotaxis : Colchicine inhibits granulocyte migration and is used in acute gout.

questions.text: Gluconeogenesis is inhibited by
questions.solution:
Correct Option - A Insulin

  • When insulin levels are high, such as in the fed state, it signals that there is sufficient glucose available for energy metabolism, and there is no need to produce additional glucose.
  • Insulin promotes glucose uptake by cells, increases glycogen synthesis, and inhibits the breakdown of glycogen (glycogenolysis) and gluconeogenesis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Glucagon, on the other hand, stimulates gluconeogenesis.

Option C - Lactate can be converted into pyruvate through a process called lactate conversion, and pyruvate can be further used in gluconeogenesis.

Option D - None of the above is incorrect

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 7-year-old child presenting with bedwetting complaints?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bed alarm:

  • A bedwetting alarm system consists of two parts:
    • Moisture sensor
    • Alarm
  • When it detects the moisture as the child passes urine, it wakes the child.
  • With time, the child gains the awareness to recognize and respond to the sensation of a full bladder, leading to control over bedwetting.
  • A bed alarm is most commonly recommended as the first line of treatment for bed wetting.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Imipramine: Imipramine is recommended when the bed alarm fails to show any result.

Option C - Desmopressin nasal spray: Desmopressin nasal spray is no longer licensed for bedwetting due to an increased incidence of side effects.

Option D - Fludrocortisone: Fludrocortisone is not used to treat bed-wetting.

questions.text: Which glycosaminoglycan (GAG) is present in synovial fluid?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option: d

Hyaluronic acid is a type of glycosaminoglycan (GAG) that is found in high concentrations in synovial fluid, which is the fluid that lubricates and cushions the joints. It is a major component of the synovial fluid and plays a crucial role in maintaining the viscoelastic properties of the fluid, allowing for smooth joint movement.

Incorrect options:

Option a. Heparin: Heparin is a GAG primarily found in mast cells and is an important anticoagulant in the bloodstream. It is not typically found in significant amounts in synovial fluid. Heparin functions by inhibiting blood clotting factors and preventing the formation of blood clots.

Option b. Keratan sulfate: Keratan sulfate is a GAG that is commonly found in various connective tissues, including cartilage, cornea, and bone. It contributes to the structural integrity of these tissues. While it may be present in trace amounts in synovial fluid, it is not the main GAG found in this fluid.

Option c. Chondroitin sulfate: Chondroitin sulfate is another GAG that is widely distributed in connective tissues, including cartilage, bone, and skin. It provides structural support and helps maintain tissue hydration. Although chondroitin sulfate may be present in small quantities in synovial fluid, it is not the primary GAG found in significant concentrations in this fluid.

questions.text: Which is the following drug that causes postural hypotension commonly?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Alpha blocker:

  • Alpha-blockers inhibit vasoconstriction; Blockade of vasoconstrictors for Alpha receptors reduces peripheral resistance and causes blood pooling in capacitance vessels; venous return and cardiac output are reduced fall in BP.

  • Postural reflex interferes with marked hypotension on standing, followed by dizziness and syncope. Hypovolemia accentuates the hypotension.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Beta blockers: Beta 1 blocker cause Hypotension while Beta 2 blockers increase BP

Option C - ACE inhibitor: Side effects of ACE inhibitor Are Hypotension especially common when starting the medication or when the dosage is increased, Dry cough, Angioedema, Hyperkalemia and skin rashes.

Option D - Angiotensin receptor blockers: Side effects of Angiotensin receptor blockers Are Hypotension ,Angioedema, Hyperkalemia ,skin rashes and They may reduce blood supply to the kidneys and can cause a temporary increase in serum creatinine levels.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A : Malignant melanoma

Malignant melanoma is a type of skin cancer that develops from melanocytes, the cells responsible for producing the pigment melanin. It often appears as an asymmetrical, irregularly bordered, and multi-colored lesion on the skin. The image given is likely to be malignant melanoma as it is consistent with the ABCDE rule that is:

  • A - Asymmetry: Look for any irregularity in shape. Melanomas often have an asymmetrical shape, meaning one half doesn't match the other half.
  • B - Border: Check the edges of the lesion. Melanomas tend to have uneven, ragged, or blurred borders, unlike benign moles that typically have smooth, well-defined borders.
  • C - Color: Examine the color of the lesion. Melanomas may display various shades of brown, black, blue, red, or white within the same lesion. Uneven distribution or changes in color should raise concerns.
  • D - Diameter: Consider the size of the lesion. While melanomas can be small, they are typically larger than benign moles. Any mole or lesion larger than 6 millimeters (about the size of a pencil eraser) should be examined by a healthcare professional.
  • E - Evolution: Monitor the evolution or changes in the lesion over time. Melanomas often undergo changes in size, shape, color, or elevation. Rapid or significant changes should be evaluated promptly.

Incorrect option

Option B : BCC - Also known as Basal cell carcinoma this type of cancer is the most common of all the skin cancers that occur. Generally, this occurs when DNA gets damaged due to exposure to ultraviolet rays and thus results in the formation of carcinomatous cells on the basal cell of the skin.

Option C: Squamous cell carcinoma - The squamous cell makes up the upper and middle layers of the skin and this type of carcinoma is the most common as it occurs in the squamous cell. Being aggressive it gets widespread in a very short period.

Option D: Nevus - Also known as moles, these are commonly pigmented skin lesions found in adults. Generally, these pigmented skin lesions are formed due to the formation of clusters of melanocytes (pigment-forming cells).

questions.text: Which of the following GAG has anticoagulant activity
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A.

Heparin is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) that possesses anticoagulant activity. It acts as a natural anticoagulant by inhibiting the activity of various clotting factors in the blood, particularly thrombin and factor Xa. Heparin is primarily synthesized and stored in mast cells, and it is released into the bloodstream when needed to prevent the formation of blood clots.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Keratan sulfate: Keratan sulfate is a GAG that is mainly found in connective tissues such as cartilage and cornea. It does not possess anticoagulant properties.

Option C. Chondroitin sulfate: Chondroitin sulfate is another GAG that is abundant in various connective tissues, including cartilage and tendons. It does not have anticoagulant activity.

Option D. Hyaluronic acid: Hyaluronic acid is a GAG that is widely distributed throughout the body, including in synovial fluid, skin, and connective tissues. It does not have anticoagulant properties.

questions.text: Which one of the listed medications acts as a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acetazolamide:

  • Acetazolamide is a sulfonamide derivative that inhibits carbonic anhydrase and improves salt, potassium, bicarbonate, and water excretion.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hydrochlorothiazide: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic

Option C - Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic

Option D - Mannitol: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic.

questions.text: Which specific glucose transporter is present in the skeletal muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - GLUT 4

GLUT 4 is the glucose transporter that is primarily found in skeletal muscle cells, as well as adipose tissue. It plays a crucial role in the uptake of glucose from the bloodstream into these target tissues.

Incorrect Options :

Option A - GLUT 1 is a glucose transporter found in various tissues, including red blood cells, the brain, and endothelial cells. It facilitates the basal uptake of glucose in these cells.

Option B - GLUT 2 is mainly found in the liver, pancreas, and small intestine. It has a role in glucose uptake and release in these organs, such as the uptake of glucose from the intestine and the release of glucose from the liver.

Option C - GLUT 3 is predominantly expressed in neurons and is responsible for glucose transport across the blood-brain barrier. It ensures a constant supply of glucose to meet the high energy demands of the brain.

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of generalised oedema and massive proteinuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nephrotic Syndrome:

  • Nephrotic syndrome is a condition characterized by the presence of significant proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia.

Incorrect Options - B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the substance that inhibits Complex 4 in the electron transport chain?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A.

Cyanide: Cyanide inhibits Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain by binding to the heme group of cytochrome c oxidase. This prevents the transfer of electrons from cytochrome c to oxygen, halting the final step of ATP synthesis.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Phenformin: Phenformin is an antidiabetic drug that does not directly inhibit Complex IV. It primarily acts by inhibiting mitochondrial ATP synthesis through a different mechanism, involving the inhibition of ATP synthase.

Option C. Rotenone: Rotenone is a pesticide and a specific inhibitor of Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) in the electron transport chain. It blocks the transfer of electrons from NADH to coenzyme Q, disrupting the normal flow of electrons through the chain.

Option D. Carboxin: Carboxin is a fungicide that inhibits succinate dehydrogenase, an enzyme involved in the Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle). It does not directly inhibit Complex IV in the electron transport chain.

questions.text: Which is most cardiotoxic anticancer drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anthracyclines:

  • Daunorubicin and doxorubicin are anthracyclines. Epirubicin, idarubicin, and mitoxantrone are other anthracycline analogs. Doxorubicin's cardiotoxicity is primarily associated with its potential to cause damage to the heart muscle, leading to a condition called cardiomyopathy.

  • It can result in symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, chest pain, and fluid retention.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide belongs to alkylating agents

Option C - Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator

Option D - Imatinib: Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

 

  • All these drugs are less cardiotoxic than anthracyclines.

questions.text: Which type of skin cancer is commonly associated with the depicted cutaneous horn in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A : Squamous cell carcinoma

  • Cutaneous horns, also known as cornu cutaneum, are conical or cylindrical projections that appear on the skin. They are composed of keratin, the same protein found in hair and nails. Cutaneous horns can develop on various areas of the body, but they are most commonly found on sun-exposed areas, such as the face, ears, and hands.
  • While cutaneous horns themselves are not cancerous, they can be associated with underlying skin conditions, including squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). In fact, approximately 20% of cutaneous horns are found to be associated with SCC. The horn-like projection is often a result of the buildup of keratinized material over an underlying skin lesion, such as a precancerous actinic keratosis or an invasive SCC. The presence of a cutaneous horn should raise suspicion for an underlying malignancy, particularly SCC

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Melanoma - Generally being a form of skin cancer that involves the melanocytes (pigment-forming cells). These cancers are aggressive as they spread out widely.

Option C: BCC - Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that occurs from damaged DNA due to exposure to ultraviolet rays and thus leading to the carcinomatous formation in the basal cell epithelium.

Option D: Actinic keratosis - Occurring in older people due to prolonged exposure to sun rays for years. In this condition, there occur rough and scaly types of skin. Thus due to long exposure to the sun, the skin becomes hard, rough, and scaly though a few of them lead to a cancerous state.

questions.text: What is the most frequently occurring amino acid in collagen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Glycine

The most common amino acid found in collagen is Glycine. Glycine makes up approximately one-third of the amino acids in the collagen protein. Its small size allows for the close packing of collagen helices, contributing to the structural stability of collagen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Proline: Proline plays a crucial role in the formation of collagen helices by introducing kinks in the protein structure.

Option B - Leucine: Leucine is a hydrophobic amino acid and is not typically abundant in collagen.

Option C - Arginine: Arginine residues in collagen contribute to the formation of intermolecular cross-links, which enhance the stability and tensile strength of collagen fibers.

questions.text: In an individual traveling to an area with endemic malaria, which of the following is the preferred chemoprophylaxis option?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Chloroquine

  • Due to sensitive strains of all 4 species, chloroquine is very efficient in treating malaria.
  • A 250 mg pill of chloroquine phosphate contains 150 mg of the base.
  • The recommended dosage is CHLOROQUINE 1 g (600 mg base) at 0 followed by 0.5 g at 6, 24, and 48 hr. Prophylaxis is another usage for it; 300 mg base weekly. The WHO has condensed the chloroquine regimen to 1 g (600 mg dosage) at 0 hours, 24 hours, and 48 hours (2-2-1 regimen).
  • Regions where there are strains that are sensitive to chloroquine
  • Areas with chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum, such as India, should take two tablets each week, starting one week before leaving the endemic area and continuing for four weeks after leaving.

Incorrect options:

Options B 

Quinine is used in uncomplicated, complicated, and cerebral malaria.

Option C

Lumefantrine is used in the treatment of MDR falciparum malaria.

Option D 

Pyrimethamine was given as chemoprophylaxis before but is not used now.

questions.text: The molecule responsible for the transport of ammonia from the brain to the liver is
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Glutamine:

Glutamine is the molecule responsible for transporting ammonia from the brain to the liver in a process called the glutamine cycle. In the brain, ammonia is converted into glutamine by the enzyme glutamine synthetase. Glutamine is then transported through the bloodstream to the liver, where it is converted back into ammonia by the enzyme glutaminase.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Leucine: Leucine is an essential amino acid involved in protein synthesis and does not play a direct role in transporting ammonia.

Option C - Lysine: Lysine is also an essential amino acid and does not have a specific role in ammonia transport.

Option D - Aspartate: Aspartate is involved in various metabolic processes but is not primarily responsible for transporting ammonia from the brain to the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for the prophylaxis of migraine?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C. Flutamide

  • Flutamide is not used for the prophylaxis of migraine. Flutamide is an antiandrogen medication primarily used in the treatment of certain hormone-dependent conditions, such as prostate cancer and hirsutism. It is not indicated or commonly prescribed for the prevention or prophylaxis of migraine headaches.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be effective in reducing the frequency and severity of migraines. It works by blocking the action of adrenaline and other stress hormones, which can trigger migraines.

Option B: Imipramine: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that is sometimes used for migraine prophylaxis. It helps regulate the levels of certain neurotransmitters in the brain, which may help prevent migraine attacks.

Option D: Flunarizine: Flunarizine is a calcium channel blocker that has been used in some countries for the prophylaxis of migraines. It works by reducing the influx of calcium into cells, which can help prevent the excessive dilation of blood vessels in the brain that is associated with migraines.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female – pain in the fingernail, on examination nail fold is seen with pus, most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Paronychia:

  • Paronychia is a condition characterized by inflammation and infection of the nail fold
  • It can result from bacterial or fungal infection or trauma to the nail fold.
  • The symptoms of paronychia often include pain, swelling, redness, and the presence of pus around the nail fold.

​​​​​​​

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Yellow nail syndrome: Yellow nail syndrome is a rare condition characterized by yellowing, thickening, and slow growth of the nails.

Option B - Psoriasis: Psoriasis can affect the nails, causing changes such as pitting, thickening, or separation from the nail bed, it is not typically associated with pain in the fingernail.

Option C - Alopecia Areata: Alopecia areata does not directly affect the nails or the nail fold.

questions.text: All of the following are found in DNA structures except
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Uracil:

Uracil is not found in DNA structures; it is one of the four nitrogenous bases found in RNA instead. DNA contains the nitrogenous bases Guanine, Adenine, Cytosine, and Thymine. Thymine replaces uracil in DNA and forms base pairs specifically with adenine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Guanine: It is one of the four nitrogenous bases found in DNA and forms base pairs with Cytosine.

Option B - Adenine: It is another nitrogenous base found in DNA and forms base pairs with Thymine.

Option C - Cytosine: It is one of the four nitrogenous bases found in DNA and forms base pairs with Guanine.

questions.text: What is the possible cause of poisoning in a farmer who has a pin-point pupil and an increase in secretions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Organophosphate poisoning:

  • Increased Secretion and pinpoint pupil is common presentation of Organophosphate poisoning.

  • Anticholinesterases (anti-ChEs) or cholinesterase inhibitors suppress the cholinesterase enzyme. They primarily inhibit both acetyl ChE and butyryl ChE. Phosphoric acid (organophosphates) or carbamic acid (carbamates) esters are the two anticholinesterases.

  • In addition to causing symptoms like nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, diarrhea, miosis, sweating, increased salivary, tracheobronchial, and gastric secretions, muscarinic, nicotinic, and central effects can also result in symptoms like bronchospasm, hypotension, muscular twitching, weakness, convulsions, and coma. The death-causing paralysis of the respiratory system.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Datura poisoning: Hallucinations, delirium, agitation, confusion, and disorientation can all result from datura toxicity. There may also be seizures. They also prevent acetylcholine from working, which causes symptoms like constipation, urine retention, dry mouth, hazy vision, and dilated pupils (mydriasis). Tachycardia, arrhythmias, and variations in blood pressure (both high and low blood pressure) can all result from datura intoxication.

Option C - Opioid poisoning: The central nervous system can be suppressed by opioids, which can result in shallow breathing, respiratory stoppage, and lethargy. symptoms are constipation, nausea, vomiting, bradycardia, hypotension, and bradycardia are all typical signs of opioid intoxication. Skin that feels clammy and cool is common.

Option D - Atropine poisoning: Dry mouth, lessened perspiration, dilated pupils (mydriasis), hazy eyesight, and urine retention are symptoms of atropine toxicity. Tachycardia, agitation, disorientation, delirium, hallucinations, constipation, discomfort in the abdomen, and flushed, dry, and heated skin are also present.

questions.text: Patient with a history of severe sunburn after only a few minutes exposure in the sun (photosensitivity) he noticed freckling in sun-exposed areas, dry skin, and changes in skin pigmentation. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Xeroderma Pigmentosa

 

Explanation:

 

The image and clinical description are classic for Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)—a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterised by extreme sensitivity to UV radiation due to defective DNA repair mechanisms.

Feature Description
Photosensitivity Severe sunburns after minimal UV exposure
Skin pigmentation Early onset of freckling, hypo- and hyperpigmented macules
Skin atrophy Dry, parchment-like skin
Ocular involvement Photophobia, conjunctivitis, corneal opacities, and lid changes
Neurological symptoms May include sensorineural deafness, ataxia, and intellectual disability
Cancer risk Markedly increased risk of basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma at a young age

 

Bloom syndrome (Option B): It is an inherited condition in which the stature of the person is shorter than the average, has a narrow face, and has skin rashes all over. In these people, there is a very high increased chance of cancer to occur.

Warts (Option C): Caused by human papillomavirus, it is characterized by rough and uneven bumps on the skin mostly on the hands, face, and feet. It is a non-cancerous growth occurring mostly in people who do have a weak immune system or people with an autoimmune disease.

Melanocytic nevus (Option D): Generally, a non-cancerous condition is caused by melanocytes ( pigment-producing cells). These are also called moles.

questions.text: Which drugs are subjected to therapeutic drug monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phenytoin:

  • Phenytoin, an antiepileptic drug, requires therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) due to its narrow therapeutic range.
  • TDM helps ensure its blood levels stay within the therapeutic range for optimal seizure control and to avoid adverse effects.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Heparin: TDM is generally unnecessary for heparin because its effects can be evaluated using other tests like aPTT or anti-Xa activity.

Option C - Aspirin: Aspirin's effects are well understood, so TDM is not typically required.

Option D - Metformin: TDM is not commonly used for metformin as its therapeutic effects relate more to glucose metabolism than precise blood levels.

questions.text: Which of the options listed below is an oral medication that directly inhibits thrombin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dabigatran:

  • Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor and is the correct answer to the question. It belongs to a class of medications called non-vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulants (NOACs) or direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs). Dabigatran directly inhibits the activity of thrombin, which is a key enzyme involved in the clotting cascade. By inhibiting thrombin, dabigatran prevents the formation of fibrin and the subsequent development of blood clots.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rivaroxaban: Rivaroxaban is an oral anticoagulant that belongs to the class of medications known as factor Xa inhibitors. It works by directly inhibiting factor Xa, another enzyme involved in the clotting cascade.

Option C - Warfarin: Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant that works by inhibiting the synthesis of certain clotting factors in the liver. It is not a direct thrombin inhibitor.

Option D - Lepirudin: Lepirudin is an intravenous direct thrombin inhibitor that is used as an anticoagulant in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. It is not administered orally.

questions.text: What is the cylinder associated with a black body and white shoulder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Oxygen:

  • Oxygen cylinders have a black body with white shoulders. This is the color coding of cylinders. Anesthetic gasses are usually supplied in cylinders that are made of molybdenum steel.
  • This allows the cylinders to be made thinner and lighter for comparable working pressures. Oxygen is stored under high pressure in cylinders and they cannot be directly administered to a patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Nitric oxide: Nitric oxide cylinders have a blue color code.

Option C - Helium: Helium cylinders have a brown color code.

Option D - Entonox: Entonox cylinders have a blue body with a white shoulder color code.

questions.text: The Pin Index of Entonox is
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: 7

The pin index for Entonox is 7. The part of the cylinder that is a solid cuboid with four faces that is attached to the anesthesia machines is called the pin index valve block. One of these faces bears the gas outlet and the pin index safety system. The index pins for some gasses are:

  • Oxygen - 2,5
  • Air - 1,5
  • Cyclopropane - 3,6

Incorrect options:

Option B: 1,5 is the Index pin for air.

Option C: 2, 5 is the Index pin for oxygen

Option D: 3, 5 is the index pin for nitrous oxide.

questions.text: Which medications exhibit zero order kinetics among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phenytoin:

  • Phenytoin exhibits zero-order kinetics, meaning a constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit of time, irrespective of its concentration.
  • This occurs due to saturation of the enzymes responsible for its metabolism.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C & D: Epinephrine, Morphine & Propranolol :

  • Follows first-order kinetics, where elimination is proportional to its concentration.

questions.text: The color of the nitrous oxide cylinder is
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Completely Blue:

  • The color code for nitrous oxide (liquid) cylinders is complete blue (french blue).
  • Anesthetic gasses are supplied in cylinders. The cylinders are made up of molybdenum steel which is an alloy.
  • Nitrous oxide is stored under high pressure in cylinders. It cannot be directly given to patients as it can lead to the danger of barotrauma, and the flow rates at high pressure are difficult to control.

Cylinder

Colour

Oxygen (gas)

Black body and white shoulder.

Nitrous Oxide (gas)

Blue

Nitrogen (gas)

Black

Air (gas)

Gray/black body with black/white shoulder

Entonox (gas)

Blue body and white/blue shoulder

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Blue body with shoulder: Blue body with the blue shoulder is the color code for Entonox.

Option C - Black body & white shoulder: Black body with a white shoulder is the color code for oxygen (gas).

Option D - Grey body & black white sholuder: Grey body and black-white shoulder is the color code for nitrogen.

questions.text: Which anti-amoebic medication, when combined with alcohol, may have caused the lady to experience symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and dizziness at a social gathering?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Metronidazole:

  • Metronidazole has a significant interaction with alcohol, which can result in a disulfiram-like reaction.

  • This reaction occurs due to the inhibition of aldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme by metronidazole, leading to an accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed.

  • Acetaldehyde is a toxic metabolite that causes unpleasant symptoms similar to a hangover, including nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, headache, and dizziness.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Nitazoxanide: Nitazoxanide is an anti-parasitic medication used to treat protozoal infections, including amoebiasis. It does not have a documented interaction with alcohol causing a disulfiram-like reaction.

Option C - Paromomycin: Paromomycin is an antibiotic used to treat intestinal infections, including amoebiasis. It does not have a documented interaction with alcohol causing a disulfiram-like reaction.

Option D - Diloxanide: Diloxanide is an anti-amoebic drug used to eliminate the cysts of Entamoeba histolytica from the intestinal tract after acute amoebic colitis. It does not have a documented interaction with alcohol causing a disulfiram-like reaction.

questions.text: Which is the best way to recognize the cylinder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Label:

  • The best way to recognize a cylinder is by its label. The color also helps to identify the cylinders.
  • The name of the gas is usually written on the neck of the cylinder.
  • The labels on the cylinder also had details about the weight of the gas, the pressure, and volume, the manufacturer, etc.
  • There are also safety instructions given on the label (including danger signs and exposure to air warnings).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Color coding:

  • Color coding is a way to identify a cylinder, but it's not the best way, as some people may not be aware of the color coding given for a cylinder.

Option C - Pin index:

  • A pin index system is also not the best way to recognize a cylinder, as the person must understand the arrangement of the pins.

Option D - All of the above:

  • All of the above are methods used to identify a cylinder but only the label is the best method.

questions.text: Hypoxic Hypoxia is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option D.

A-V shunt : An A-V (arteriovenous) shunt refers to an abnormal connection between an artery and a vein, bypassing the capillary network.  It is associated with hypoxic hypoxia

Incorrect options:

Option A. CO poisoning: Carbon monoxide (CO) can lead to anemic hypoxia. CO has a strong affinity for hemoglobin, binding to it more readily than oxygen. This reduces the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, resulting in decreased oxygen delivery to the tissues.

Option B. HCN poisoning: Hydrogen cyanide (HCN) poisoning can cause Histotoxic hypoxia. HCN inhibits cellular respiration by interfering with the electron transport chain, impairing the utilization of oxygen by the cells.

Option C. Ischemia: Ischemia refers to inadequate blood flow to tissues, which can result in stagnant hypoxia. Reduced blood flow means less oxygen is delivered to the affected tissues, leading to hypoxia.

questions.text: Which anti-asthma drug should be avoided with Erythromycin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Theophylline:

  • Among the options provided, the anti-asthma drug that is typically avoided with erythromycin is Theophylline. Erythromycin is known to inhibit the metabolism of theophylline, leading to an increase in its blood levels. This can result in theophylline toxicity, which may manifest as symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, tremors, rapid heartbeat, and even seizures.

  • Theophylline is a bronchodilator used in the management of asthma and other respiratory conditions. It works by relaxing the smooth muscles in the airways, thereby improving breathing. As it is metabolised by cytochrome P450 and erythromycin is a Microsomal enzyme (cytochrome P450) inhibitors causing increased theophylline level..

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Salbutamol: There is no significant interaction between salbutamol (also known as albuterol) and erythromycin. Salbutamol is a short-acting beta-agonist bronchodilator used for the relief of acute asthma symptoms.

Option C - Terbutaline: Like salbutamol, terbutaline is a beta-agonist bronchodilator. It does not have a documented interaction with erythromycin that requires avoidance.

Option D - Ipratropium: Ipratropium is an anticholinergic bronchodilator used for the treatment of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It does not have a significant interaction with erythromycin.

questions.text: PR interval in ECG denotes which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Conduction through AV nodes:

  • The PR interval represents the time it takes for the electrical impulse to travel from the atria, through the atrioventricular (AV) node, and into the ventricles of the heart. It is measured from the beginning of the P wave (which represents atrial depolarization) to the beginning of the QRS complex (which represents ventricular depolarization).
  • The AV node acts as a gateway between the atria and the ventricles, slowing down the electrical impulse to allow for proper coordination and synchronization of atrial contraction before ventricular contraction. The PR interval, therefore, reflects the time it takes for the electrical signal to travel through the AV node.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ventricular depolarization: It is marked by the R wave of the ECG.

Option C - Ventricular repolarization: Ventricular repolarization is represented by the T wave on an electrocardiogram (ECG).

Option D - Atrial depolarization: It is represented by the P wave of the ECG.

questions.text: What is the suggested follow-up treatment for a patient post valve replacement?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Warfarin

  • Among the options provided, a patient who has undergone valve replacement surgery will typically require follow-up treatment with warfarin. Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant medication that works by inhibiting the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors in the liver. It helps to prevent the formation of blood clots and reduce the risk of thromboembolic events, such as strokes and deep vein thrombosis.

  • After valve replacement surgery, especially with mechanical heart valves, the risk of blood clot formation on the valve surface is increased. Therefore, long-term anticoagulation therapy with warfarin is often recommended to maintain adequate blood-thinning and prevent clot-related complications.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are a class of medications used primarily to manage hypertension and heart failure. While they have important roles in the treatment of certain cardiac conditions, they are not typically the primary follow-up treatment after valve replacement surgery.

Option C - Beta blockers: Beta blockers are commonly used in the management of various cardiovascular conditions, such as hypertension, angina, and certain arrhythmias. While beta blockers may be prescribed as part of the post-operative care following valve replacement surgery, they are not specifically indicated as the primary follow-up treatment.

Option D - Thiazides: Thiazides are a type of diuretic medication used to treat hypertension and edema. They are not typically the primary follow-up treatment after valve replacement surgery.

questions.text: Antidote for opioid poisoning is?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Naloxone

  • The antidote for opioid poisoning is naloxone. Naloxone is a specific opioid receptor antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioid overdose. It works by binding to the opioid receptors in the brain, displacing the opioid molecules and reversing the respiratory depression, sedation, and other opioid-related effects.
  • Naloxone is commonly used in emergency situations to restore normal breathing and consciousness in individuals experiencing opioid overdose. It can be administered intravenously, intramuscularly, or intranasally. Naloxone has a rapid onset of action and a relatively short duration, so repeated doses or continuous infusion may be necessary in severe cases.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Pethidine (also known as meperidine): Pethidine is an opioid analgesic. It is not an antidote for opioid poisoning and should not be used for reversing the effects of opioid overdose.

Option C: Flumazenil: Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepine overdose or to reverse the sedative effects of benzodiazepines during anesthesia. It is not effective for reversing the effects of opioid overdose.

Option D: Physostigmine: Physostigmine is a reversible cholinesterase inhibitor primarily used to treat anticholinergic toxicity or overdose. It is not indicated for opioid overdose and is not effective as an opioid antidote.

questions.text: Hyperkalemia refers to the serum potassium concentration of _____.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 6.0 mEq/L: 

  • Hyperkalemia refers to an elevated level of serum potassium more than 5.5 mEq/L.
  • Normal value of serum potassium is 3.5 to 5.5 mEq/l.

Incorrect options

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Koplik spots are seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Measles:

  • Koplik spots are pathognomonic features characterized by small, white-colored bumps on the erythematous base that appear in the mouth in the prodromal stage of measles.
  • Prodromal phase of measles
    • Fever - 1st manifestation around 10th day.
    • 3 C's - Cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis.
    • Pathognomonic feature - Kopliks spot near molar appears after 2 days of fever.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Koplik spots are not seen in these conditions.

questions.text: Monoclonal antibody used in cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rituximab:

  • Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of certain types of cancer. It specifically targets and binds to a protein called CD20, which is found on the surface of B-lymphocytes. Rituximab works by promoting the destruction of cancerous B-cells and modulating the immune response against cancer.

  • Rituximab is primarily used in the treatment of B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), including follicular lymphoma, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). It is also utilized in the management of certain autoimmune disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and pemphigus vulgaris.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cisplatin: Cisplatin is a platinum-based chemotherapy drug that is not a monoclonal antibody. It works by damaging the DNA in cancer cells, leading to their death.

Option C - 5-Fluorouracil: 5-Fluorouracil is a chemotherapy drug that inhibits the synthesis of DNA and RNA, leading to the destruction of cancer cells. It is not a monoclonal antibody.

Option D - Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a chemotherapy drug that interferes with DNA synthesis and cell division. It is used in the treatment of various cancers, as well as autoimmune conditions. However, it is not a monoclonal antibody.

questions.text: What is found in skeletal muscle among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 

Option A.

  • GLUT stands for glucose transporter, and GLUT proteins facilitate the transport of glucose across cell membranes. Among the options given, GLUT-4 is the glucose transporter that is primarily found in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue.
  • GLUT-4 is responsible for insulin-regulated glucose uptake into skeletal muscle cells. It plays a crucial role in maintaining blood glucose homeostasis. When insulin is released in response to high blood glucose levels, it triggers the translocation of GLUT-4 from intracellular vesicles to the cell membrane of skeletal muscle cells. This allows GLUT-4 to transport glucose from the bloodstream into the muscle cells, where it can be utilized for energy production or stored as glycogen.

Incorrect options:

Option B. GLUT-5: GLUT-5 is primarily found in the small intestine and is responsible for the uptake of fructose, not glucose. It is less relevant to skeletal muscle glucose uptake.

Option C. GLUT-7: GLUT-7 is mainly found in the liver and is involved in glucose uptake and release in hepatocytes. It is not present in skeletal muscle.

Option D. GLUT-2: GLUT-2 is found in various tissues, including the liver, pancreas, and small intestine. It facilitates glucose uptake in these tissues and is involved in glucose sensing and transport across the cell membrane. However, GLUT-2 is not primarily present in skeletal muscle.

questions.text: Identify the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hantavirus:

  • Hantavirus is a single-stranded RNA virus responsible for causing Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome. The main target site for Hantavirus is the lungs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Influenza Virus: Influenza is caused by Orthomyxovirus and is a single-stranded RNA virus. It has neuraminidase and hemagglutinin spike proteins.

Option C - Adenovirus: It is a double-stranded DNA virus that is responsible for causing respiratory illness.

Option D - None of the Above: This option cannot be the answer since the Hantavirus is an organism shown in the picture.

questions.text: What are the effects of dietary fibers?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Reduces intestinal transit time:

  • Dietary fibers are known to increase stool bulk and promote regular bowel movements, thus reducing intestinal transit time. They add bulk to the stool, making it easier to pass through the digestive system and preventing constipation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - No role in metabolism:

  • This is incorrect because dietary fibers play a significant role in metabolism. They are not digested by human enzymes, but they are fermented by gut bacteria in the colon, producing short-chain fatty acids that can be utilized as an energy source.

Option C - Causes constipation:

  • This is incorrect because dietary fibers actually help prevent constipation. They add bulk to the stool, soften it, and promote regular bowel movements.

Option D - Increased blood Glucose:

  • This is incorrect because dietary fibers have the opposite effect on blood glucose levels. Soluble fibers, in particular, can slow down the absorption of glucose, leading to a more gradual and controlled rise in blood glucose levels after a meal.

questions.text: All of the following can result in gynaecomastia except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Aromatase inhibitors:

  • Aromatase inhibitors are medications used to treat hormone receptor-positive breast cancer in postmenopausal women.
  • They work by reducing estrogen levels in the body through inhibition of the enzyme aromatase, which converts androgens to estrogens.
  • Aromatase inhibitors are not typically associated with gynecomastia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Liver failure: Liver failure can disrupt hormone metabolism, leading to hormonal imbalances such as increased estrogen levels, which may contribute to gynecomastia.

Option B - Spironolactone: Spironolactone, an aldosterone receptor antagonist, can interfere with androgen activity, potentially leading to gynecomastia.

Option C - Digoxin: While the mechanism is not well understood, digoxin, a cardiac medication, has been associated with gynecomastia in some cases.

questions.text: Which test is most appropriate for the clinical diagnosis of a 3-year-old patient experiencing intermittent loose motions and weight loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anti-tissue transglutaminase Antibody:

  • The most-likely provisional diagnosis in a 3-year-old child experiencing intermittent loose motions and weight loss is celiac disease.
  • The Anti- tissue transglutaminase Antibody test is a primary screening test for celiac disease.
  • It detects the presence of transglutaminase, an enzyme that causes an autoimmune response in celiac disease on gluten ingestion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anti-Mitochondrial Antibody (AMA):AMA is highly specific for primary biliary cirrhosis, which is a chronic liver disease characterized by progressive destruction of the small bile ducts within the liver.

Option C - Anti-SCL 70 Antibody:The presence of anti-SCL 70 antibodies is strongly associated with systemic sclerosis, a chronic connective tissue disease characterized by fibrosis and vascular abnormalities affecting the skin, internal organs, and blood vessels.

Option D - Anti-Microsomal Antibody: It is also known as Anti-Thyroid Microsomal Antibody or Anti-Thyroid Peroxidase Antibody.

questions.text: What are the consequences of experimental muscle spindle sectioning in frogs?

choices.text: Voluntary Axn lost but stretch reflex present
Voluntary Axn present, stretch reflex is lost.

questions.solution:
Correct option: 

Option C:

Both are lost: This option is correct. Cutting the muscle spindle disrupts the sensory input from the spindle, leading to the loss of both voluntary Axn and the stretch reflex.

Incorrect Option :

Option A: Voluntary Axn (Action) and stretch reflex present: This option is incorrect. When the muscle spindle is cut, the sensory input from the spindle is disrupted, leading to the loss of the stretch reflex. As a result, the stretch reflex would not be present.

Option B: Voluntary Axn lost but stretch reflex present: This option is incorrect. Cutting the muscle spindle interrupts the sensory input to the spinal cord, resulting in the loss of both voluntary Axn and the stretch reflex. Therefore, neither the voluntary Axn nor the stretch reflex would be present.

Option D: Both voluntary Axn present, stretch reflex is lost: This option is incorrect. When the muscle spindle is cut, the sensory input necessary for the stretch reflex is disrupted, resulting in the loss of the stretch reflex. Therefore, the stretch reflex would not be present.

questions.text: Which of the following parasite is transmitted by reduviid bug?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - T. Cruzi:

  • This parasite causes Chagas disease, also known as American trypanosomiasis. It is transmitted by the triatomine (reduviid) bug, commonly known as the "kissing bug." When the bug bites a person, it can defecate near the bite wound, and if the person scratches the area, the parasite can enter the bloodstream through the broken skin.

Incorrect Options

Option A - T. Brucei: It is known for causing African Trypanosomiasis, commonly known as Sleeping Sickness transmitted by tsetse fly.

Option C - Leishmania Donovani: It is known for causing visceral leishmaniasis, transmitted by sandflies.

Option D - Both A & B: Although both parasites belong to the genus Trypanosoma, T. Cruzi is transmitted by reduviid bug, and T. brucei is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

questions.text: All are signs of adequate breastfeeding in a 2-month-old infant, except?

choices.text: Baby sleeps for 2-3 hours after feeding

questions.solution:
Correct option A: Baby sleeps for 2-3 hours after feeding: Baby sleeping for 1-2 hours after feeding is a sign of adequate breastfeeding.

Incorrect options: Options B, C, and D are signs of adequate breastfeeding.

questions.text: What medications should be administered to manage a patient who is 34 weeks pregnant and experiencing seizures, with a blood pressure reading of 200/110 mmHg?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IV labetalol plus magnesium sulphate:

  • The combination of intravenous (IV) labetalol and magnesium sulfate is commonly used in the management of severe hypertension and seizures associated with preeclampsia or eclampsia.

  • Labetalol is a beta-blocker that helps lower blood pressure by blocking the effects of certain stress hormones on the heart and blood vessels. Magnesium sulfate is an anticonvulsant medication that helps prevent and control seizures in women with preeclampsia or eclampsia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oral Labetalol: Oral Labetalol alone may not be sufficient for immediate control of severe hypertension and seizure activity in this critical situation. IV administration allows for rapid onset of action.

Option C - IV Lorazepam: IV Lorazepam is a sedative and anti-anxiety medication but is not the first-line treatment for severe hypertension and seizures associated with preeclampsia or eclampsia.
