Option C. Fomepizole is used as an antidote in case of methanol poisoning.

Option D. Pethidine itself is a kind of opioid used for relieving pain. The antidote for pethidine is Naloxone.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Investigation of choice for endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option D: Laparoscopy

Laparoscopy:

  • Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of endometriosis.
  • It is a minimally invasive surgical procedure where a thin, lighted instrument (laparoscope) is inserted through a small incision in the abdomen to visualize the pelvic organs.
  • During laparoscopy, the surgeon can directly visualize and biopsy endometrial lesions, providing a definitive diagnosis of endometriosis.
  • It allows for evaluation and staging of the disease, guiding appropriate treatment decisions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: CT (Computed Tomography)

  • CT scans are not the investigation of choice for diagnosing endometriosis.
  • CT scans provide detailed cross-sectional images of the body, but they are not specific or sensitive enough to identify endometriosis lesions accurately.

Option B: MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging)

  • While MRI can be helpful in some cases to evaluate certain features of endometriosis, it is not the primary investigation of choice.
  • MRI may be used to assess the extent of endometriosis and evaluate structures like the ovaries, uterus, and pelvic organs.
  • However, laparoscopy remains the gold standard for definitive diagnosis and visualization of endometriosis lesions.

Option C: USG (Ultrasound)

  • Transvaginal ultrasound (USG) is a non-invasive imaging modality that can provide some information about endometriosis, such as the presence of ovarian endometriomas (cysts).
  • However, it is not the primary investigation of choice for diagnosing endometriosis.
  • USG may show indirect signs of endometriosis, but it cannot definitively confirm the presence or extent of endometrial implants.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-CD 20 monoclonal antibodies is used in cancer therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rituximab:

  • Rituximab is an anti-CD 20 monoclonal antibody used in cancer treatments.
  • It blocks the CD20 receptor, which is a marker of B-lymphocyte.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Methotrexate is an antimetabolite. It is also a chemotherapy agent and immune suppressant.

Option C. Cisplatin is an antineoplastic agent.

Option D. 5-Fluorouracil is a cytotoxic drug.

questions.text: In which disease are Koplik spots observed?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: Measles

Koplik spots are small white or bluish-white spots that appear on the mucous membranes of the mouth and throat. They are a characteristic feature of measles.

Incorrect options

Option A: Mumps- Mumps primarily affects the salivary glands, leading to swelling and pain in the cheeks and jaw. However, mumps does not cause Koplik spots.

Option C: Rubella- Rubella, also known as German measles, typically presents with a rash that starts on the face and spreads to the rest of the body. However, Koplik spots are not seen in rubella.

Option D: Varicella- Varicella, commonly known as chickenpox, is characterized by a widespread rash with fluid-filled blisters. Koplik spots are not associated with varicella.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action for a patient presenting with one eye displaying convergent squint and visual acuity of 6/60, while the other eye has no squint but also displays visual acuity of 6/60?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D. 

When a person presents with squint (strabismus), it is important to evaluate the refractive error in both eyes to determine the appropriate course of action. In this case, one eye has a squint with vision 6/60, and the other eye has no squint with vision 6/60.

Refraction is necessary to assess if refractive error (such as myopia, hyperopia, or astigmatism) is causing the reduced vision in both eyes. Refractive correction can often improve vision significantly, especially if there is a high refractive error.

Once the refractive error has been corrected, if the squint persists, further evaluation and management, such as squint surgery or other interventions, can be considered based on the underlying cause of the squint. It's essential to identify and address any refractive error before planning specific treatments for the squint.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. MRI: An MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is not the immediate next step in a case of squint with reduced vision. MRI is typically reserved for cases where there are signs or symptoms suggesting neurological involvement, which might indicate a more serious underlying condition. Routine squint evaluation starts with a comprehensive eye examination and refraction.

Option B. Squint surgery: Squint surgery might be a consideration, but it should not be the immediate next step without a proper evaluation of the refractive status of the eyes. Refractive errors can cause reduced vision and might be the primary cause of the visual impairment in this case.

Option C. Botulinum toxin: Botulinum toxin injections are sometimes used in the management of specific types of squint, but the decision to use this treatment depends on the underlying cause and the assessment by an ophthalmologist. It is not the immediate next step without a comprehensive eye examination and refraction.

questions.text: In a labor room, after delivery and placenta removal, what is the primary reason for uncontrolled bleeding in a multigravida woman, leading to postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Atonic PPH

  • Atonic PPH refers to excessive postpartum bleeding caused by the failure of the uterus to contract effectively after childbirth.
  • It is the most common cause of PPH, accounting for the majority of cases.
  • Inadequate uterine contractions prevent the blood vessels in the placental site from constricting, leading to persistent bleeding.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Traumatic PPH

  • Traumatic PPH occurs due to damage or trauma to the genital tract during childbirth.
  • It can be caused by lacerations, tears, or injury to the cervix, vagina, perineum, or uterus.
  • While traumatic PPH can occur, it is less common than atonic PPH.

Option C: Clotting factor deficiency

  • Clotting factor deficiency, such as a deficiency in factors VIII, IX, or von Willebrand factor, can lead to abnormal blood clotting and an increased risk of bleeding.
  • While clotting factor deficiencies can contribute to PPH in some cases, they are not as common as atonic PPH.

Option D: Retained placenta

  • Retained placenta occurs when fragments of the placenta or membranes remain in the uterus after delivery.
  • This can cause ongoing bleeding and is an important consideration when assessing postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: Deficiency of Vitamin B12 leads to what type of anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Macrocytic hypochromic:

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency indirectly causes folate deficiency leading to macrocytic hypochromic anemia.
  • Other manifestations include:
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
    • Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Normochromic means that the cell is of normal color. Normocytic means the blood cell is of normal size. In vitamin B12 deficiency, neither of these happens.

Option B. Microcytic means the blood cells are very small in size. In vitamin B12 deficiency, the blood cells produced are extremely large compared to the normal size.

Option D. One of the options is right.

questions.text: What is the origin of the Sustainable Development Goals?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-United Nations :

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were designed by the United Nations (UN). The SDGs are a set of global goals adopted by UN member states in 2015 as part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. These goals aim to address various social, economic, and environmental challenges faced by countries around the world.

Incorrect Options

Option A: UNICEF- While UNICEF is a part of the United Nations system it is not solely responsible for designing the Sustainable Development Goals.

Option C: WHO-. While WHO contributes to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals, it is not solely responsible for designing them.

Option D: Government of India- The Government of India is not responsible for designing the Sustainable Development Goals.

questions.text: What would be the diagnosis for a diabetic patient experiencing an abrupt vision loss, having a visual acuity of 6/60, with a fundus picture provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - CRAO: 

  • The given image shows a cherry-red spot. The orange reflex from the intact choroid stands out at the thin foveola, in contrast to the surrounding pale retina, giving rise to a ‘cherry-red spot’ appearance.
  • Sudden loss of vision and cherry red spot are characteristic of Central Retinal Artery Occlusion.
  • CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion): CRAO occurs when there is a sudden blockage in the central retinal artery, leading to a severe and immediate loss of vision.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Cherry red spot is not seen in these conditions.

questions.text: N95 respirator is used for:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Airborne precautions:

  • Airborne infections are one of the five modes of transmission of diseases. N95 masks protect from most diseases that arise through airborne transmission.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Droplet precautions: N95 masks do not provide complete protection from droplet spread infection. The expelled droplets can cause infection on coming in contact with even the skin or conjunctiva.

Option C - Contact precautions: Using an N95 respirator alone is not essential to preventing diseases that could be transmitted through contact with a patient.

Option D - All of the above: N95 alone does not protect from diseases requiring contact and droplet precautions. So this option is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the recommended dosage of mifepristone for emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: 25 mg

  • Mifepristone is a medication used for emergency contraception, also known as the "morning-after pill." It is most effective when taken as soon as possible after unprotected intercourse but no later than 72 hours (3 days) after.
  • The recommended dose of mifepristone for emergency contraception is 25 mg. This single oral dose is taken as a single tablet.

Incorrect options:

Options B, C, and D: These dosage are incorrect for emergency contraception.

questions.text: What are the advantages of using contact lenses instead of eyeglasses?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Less prismatic effect:

  • Contact lenses are placed directly on the eye's surface, reducing the prismatic effect that can occur with spectacles.
  • Prismatic effect refers to the displacement of light as it passes through a lens, causing objects to appear shifted or distorted. Thicker the lens greater the prismatic effect.
  • Contact lenses, being in direct contact with the eye, minimize the prismatic effect.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These are not the advantages of using contact lens over spectacles.

questions.text: Kyoto Protocol is for
questions.solution:
Correct option C-To reduce green-house gas emissions :

The Kyoto Protocol is an international treaty that was adopted in Kyoto, Japan, in 1997 under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Its main objective is to combat climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The protocol sets binding targets for industrialized countries to reduce their emissions of six greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide, over specific commitment periods.

 

Incorrect Options

Option A:To improve water sanitization- The Kyoto Protocol does not specifically focus on water sanitization.

Option B: To study food and nutrition- The Kyoto Protocol is not related to the study of food and nutrition.

Option D: To do water chlorination-  The Kyoto Protocol does not deal with water chlorination.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the double decidual sign on ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Uterine gestational sac

  • The correct option is "Uterine gestational sac". The double decidual sign refers to the presence of two concentric rings, representing the decidua capsularis and the decidua parietalis, around the gestational sac in the uterus. This sign is commonly seen in early intrauterine pregnancy and is indicative of a developing embryo within the uterine cavity.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Pseudo gestational sac: A pseudo gestational sac is a fluid collection within the endometrial cavity that mimics a gestational sac but lacks an embryo. It is typically seen in cases of ectopic pregnancy.

Option C: Threatened Abortion: Threatened abortion refers to vaginal bleeding during early pregnancy, but it does not specifically relate to the double decidual sign.

Option D: Ectopic pregnancy: An ectopic pregnancy occurs when the fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, commonly in the fallopian tube. It does not typically exhibit the double decidual sign, as it occurs outside the uterine cavity.

questions.text: How would you approach the treatment of a 40-year-old male with fever, abdominal pain, and a diagnosis of HIV-TB?

choices.text: First start ATT then give ART
First start ART and then give ATT

questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: First start ATT then give ART

Tuberculosis is an opportunistic infection commonly seen in individuals with HIV. The primary goal is to control and treat the active tuberculosis infection using ATT. Once the tuberculosis is under control and the patient's condition has stabilized, ART can be initiated to manage the HIV infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: ATT and ART simultaneously- While both treatments are necessary for managing HIV-TB co-infection, initiating them simultaneously may increase the risk of drug interactions and overlapping side effects.

Option C: ATT only- Treating tuberculosis alone without addressing the underlying HIV infection is not recommended in HIV-TB co-infection cases. 

Option D: First start ART and then give ATT- Initiating ART before starting ATT may lead to an immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) in patients with active tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common organism causing pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option D: Chlamydia

  • Chlamydia trachomatis: Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common organism causing pelvic inflammatory disease. It is a sexually transmitted infection that can ascend from the lower genital tract to the upper reproductive organs, leading to inflammation and infection. Chlamydia trachomatis is responsible for a significant number of cases of PID.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Gardnerella vaginalis: Gardnerella vaginalis is associated with bacterial vaginosis, which is a condition characterized by an imbalance of vaginal bacteria. While bacterial vaginosis can increase the risk of developing PID, Gardnerella vaginalis is not the primary causative organism for PID.

Option B: Bacteroids: Bacteroids are a group of anaerobic bacteria that are commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract. They are not typically associated with the development of PID.

Option C: Neisseria gonorrhoeae: While Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common sexually transmitted infection, it is not the most common organism causing PID. However, it can be a significant cause of PID in some cases.

questions.text: McNaughten's rule is?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C:

In India, the IPC 84 follows McNaughton's rule because it says that when an individual does an act or crime with an unsound mind. So, at the time of the crime, the person forgot about the nature of the act and could not understand whether he or she was doing something wrong or contrary to the law, equivalent to McNaughten's rule.

Incorrect options:

Option A: According to section 82 under the Indian Penal Code states that when a child below 7 years old commits an action or a crime will not be considered an offense. As the child is immature at that particular age, he cannot commit any crime with hidden intentions.

Option B: Act 83 is also the same because it states when a child above 7 years and under 12 years old commits a crime with immature understanding. So, it is not an offense as children between 7 to 12 years do not know the future consequences of their actions.

Option D: According to section 85, nothing will be an offense committed by a person incapable of judgment because of the intoxication caused against that individual's will. As the individual was intoxicated, the person lost the understanding of right and wrong, and that individual did the crime without knowledge.

questions.text: Where is the late rupture of tubal pregnancy commonly observed in terms of anatomical location?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Interstitium: The interstitial or intramural portion of the fallopian tube is the narrowest part of the tube and is less elastic compared to other parts. As a tubal pregnancy progresses, the fertilized egg may continue to grow and cause the fallopian tube to stretch. Due to its narrow nature, late rupture in the interstitial portion is more likely to occur as the tube becomes unable to accommodate the growing pregnancy.
Because of the thick and vascular musculature of the uterine wall with greater distensibility, the fetus grows dissecting the muscle fibres for a longer period (12-14 weeks) before termination occurs.

Incorrect Options:

  • Rupture in the fimbriae (option b), ampulla (option c), or isthmus (option d) of the fallopian tube is less common in late-stage tubal pregnancies. The fimbriae and isthmus are not as susceptible to late rupture because they have more capacity to expand and accommodate the growing pregnancy.

While late rupture is relatively less common overall, when it does occur, it is more likely to happen in the interstitial portion of the fallopian tube due to its anatomical characteristics.

questions.text: African suburb, all population given chemoprophylaxis for Malaria. This is
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: Primary

  • Primary prevention aims to prevent the occurrence of a disease or condition before it develops. In the case of malaria, primary prevention measures focus on reducing the risk of acquiring the infection. Chemoprophylaxis, which involves the use of antimalarial medications, is one of the strategies used to prevent malaria in high-risk areas. By administering chemoprophylaxis to the entire population, the goal is to prevent the initial transmission of the malarial parasite and reduce the incidence of the disease.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Primordial - Primordial prevention refers to strategies that target the underlying social, economic, and environmental determinants of health. Providing chemoprophylaxis to the population does not address these broader determinants but instead directly targets the prevention of malaria itself.

Option C: Secondary- Secondary prevention involves early detection and prompt treatment of a disease. Chemoprophylaxis, in this case, is not aimed at detecting or treating existing cases of malaria but rather preventing the occurrence of new cases.

Option D: Tertiary- Tertiary prevention focuses on managing and reducing the complications and disabilities associated with a disease. Providing chemoprophylaxis to the entire population is not an intervention targeted at managing complications of malaria but rather preventing its occurrence.

questions.text: In a woman who had sexual intercourse 96 hours ago, which contraceptive method is the most appropriate choice?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device)

  • IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device): The IUCD, also known as a copper T, is a small device inserted into the uterus by a healthcare professional. It provides long-term contraception and can also be used as an emergency contraceptive method. It is effective when inserted within 120 hours (5 days) of unprotected intercourse, making it a suitable choice in this scenario.

Incorrect options:

Option A: OCP (Oral Contraceptive Pills): Oral contraceptive pills, commonly known as birth control pills, are taken daily to prevent pregnancy. However, they are not the best choice for emergency contraception after 96 hours (4 days) of unprotected intercourse. OCPs are most effective when taken within 72 hours (3 days) of intercourse.

Option C: Mifepristone: Mifepristone, also known as the "abortion pill," is primarily used for medical abortion. It is not typically used as a contraceptive method after unprotected intercourse.

Option D: Progesterone-only pills: Progesterone-only pills, also known as mini-pills, are a form of oral contraception that contains only progestin hormones. They are taken daily to prevent pregnancy. However, their effectiveness as emergency contraception after 96 hours is limited, and they are not considered the best option in this scenario.

questions.text: A 72-year-old farmer was presented in the hospital with pinpoint pupil & increased secretions. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Organophosphorus poisoning:

Organophosphorus poisoning generally occurs after respiratory, oral, or dermal exposure to nerve agents or organophosphorus pesticides. The onset symptoms of this specific disease are excessive lacrimation and saliva production, tiny pupils(miosis) , vomiting, diarrhea, excessive sweating, confusion, etc. So, as farmers are experiencing pinpoint pupils and increased secretion, the diagnosis is organophosphorus poisoning.

  • The primary treatment of Organophosphorus poisoning in emergency cases is stabilization. The experts will stabilize the breathing, decontaminate the body to stop further exposure and use intravenous fluids to clear the system from the toxins.
  • But, in non-emergency cases, the healthcare provider will give supportive therapy and stabilize the breathing using atropine (drug).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alcohol poisoning: Alcohol poisoning is a severe and deadly condition. It quickly affects heart rate, breathing, gag reflex, and body temperature. So, it often leads to coma and even death.

Option B - Opioid poisoning: Opioid poisoning occurs when there is excessive stimulation on the pathway of opiate. It eventually leads to lower respiratory effort and death. It can also cause pinpoint pupils but there is no increased body secretions.

Option D: Datura poisoning: Datura poisoning after 60 minutes of ingestion. The symptoms are dry skin and mouth, respiratory arrest, urinary retention, delirium, and tachycardia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a measure of Dispersion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option - D: Mean

The mean is a measure of central tendency and not a measure of dispersion. To obtain the mean, the individual observations are first added together and then divided by the number of observations.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Standard error- Standard error is a measure of the variability or dispersion of sample means around the population mean.

Option B - Variance- Variance is a measure of dispersion that quantifies the spread of data points around the mean.

Option C - Range- Range is a measure of dispersion that indicates the difference between the highest and lowest values in a dataset.

questions.text: What is the primary cause of MALIGNANT OTITIS EXTERNA?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

  • Malignant otits externa is the pseudomonas infection of external ear mainly affecting elderly diabetics or people using immunosuppressive medications.
  • Early symptoms resemble diffuse otitis externa, with development of granulations.
  • Cranial nerves may get involved; first cranial nerve to be affected - facial nerve → facial palsy; subsequently, the lower cranial nerves and jugular foramen can be involved.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause various types of infections, including otitis externa. However, it is not the most common cause of malignant otitis externa. Malignant otitis externa is typically associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

Option B - Streptococcus pyogenes: Streptococcus pyogenes, also known as Group A Streptococcus, is a common pathogen responsible for various infections, including strep throat and skin infections. However, it is not the most common cause of malignant otitis externa.

Option C - Haemophilus influenza: Haemophilus influenza, particularly the non-typeable strains, can cause acute otitis media, sinusitis, and other respiratory tract infections. While it can occasionally be associated with otitis externa, it is not the most common cause of malignant otitis externa.

questions.text: Which muscle pairs aid in the processes of both opening and closing the eustachian tube?

choices.text: Tensor veli palatini and levator veli palatini
Tensor tympani and tensor veli palatini

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tensor veli palatini and levator veli palatini:

The tensor veli palatini muscle helps to open the Eustachian tube by tensing the soft palate and pulling it laterally and inferiorly.

The levator veli palatini muscle contracts during swallowing and yawning to elevate the soft palate and close the nasopharyngeal orifice of the Eustachian tube.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A- Palatopharyngeus and salpingopharyngeus:

  • They elevate and shorten the pharynx during swallowing.

Option C- Tensor tympani and tensor veli palatini:

  • The tensor tympani muscle is located within the middle ear and is involved in dampening the vibrations of the ossicles to protect the inner ear from loud sounds.

Option D- Stylohyoid and geniohyoid:

  • The stylohyoid and geniohyoid muscles are both muscles of the neck that contribute to movements of the hyoid bone and tongue.

questions.text: What is the value of MAC in cases of severe malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Option D: 11.5 cms

  • This choice represents the cutoff for severe acute malnutrition according to the WHO guidelines. A MAC measurement of 11.5 cms or less would indeed indicate severe malnutrition.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MAC) is a commonly used anthropometric measurement to assess nutritional status, particularly for identifying severe malnutrition in children. MAC provides an estimate of muscle and fat stores in the upper arm and is an indicator of body composition and nutritional reserves.
  • In severe malnutrition, the MAC measurement is typically below a certain cutoff point. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines a MAC of less than 11.5 cms as a criterion for severe acute malnutrition in children aged 6-59 months.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 14.5 cms

  • A MAC measurement of 14.5 cms would not be indicative of severe malnutrition. This value is within the normal range and does not suggest severe wasting or nutritional deficiency.

Option B: 13.5 cms

  • Similar to the previous choice, a MAC measurement of 13.5 cms would still fall within the normal range and would not indicate severe malnutrition.

Option C: 12.5 cms

  • MAC equal to or greater than 125 mm(12.5cms ) indicates No Acute Malnutrition
  • Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM): MAC less than 115 mm.
  • Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM): MAC between 115 mm and 125 mm.

questions.text: What is the most frequently reported symptom of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Neck node:

  • Enlargement of cervical lymph nodes is one of the most common presenting features in nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). The lymph nodes in the apex of the posterior triangle and the upper jugular region are often the first to be involved, along with retropharyngeal nodes. Supraclavicular nodes are the last to be involved and are a sign of advanced disease.
  • The most common lymph node involved is LN between the angle of the jaw and mastoid and LN along the spinal accessory and in the posterior triangle of the HO’s triangle.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nasal obstruction: Nasal obstruction can be a symptom of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, but it is not the most common presenting complaint. Other conditions, such as allergies, sinusitis, or nasal polyps, are more commonly associated with nasal obstruction. However, as the tumor grows in the nasopharynx, it can eventually cause nasal obstruction.

Option B - Epistaxis: Epistaxis, or nosebleeds, can occur in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. However, it is not the most common presenting complaint.

Option D - Anosmia: Anosmia in nasopharyngeal carcinoma can occur due to nasal obstruction. This is more common in advanced and large tumors.

questions.text: In Marasmus, the mid-arm muscle circumference is less than:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: 11.5 cm

  • In the case of Marasmus, which is a form of severe acute malnutrition characterized by overall wasting and severe weight loss, the MUAC measurement is significantly reduced. The cut off value for MUAC in Marasmus is generally set at 11.5 mm or less.
  • Therefore, in the given options, the correct answer is 11.5.
  • A MUAC measurement less than 11.5 cm indicates severe wasting and is consistent with the diagnosis of Marasmus.

Incorrect Options:

  • The incorrect choices B, C, and D are higher values and do not reflect the significant wasting and severe weight loss observed in Marasmus.
  • MUAC values of 17, 19, or 21 cm would indicate a healthier or more normal nutritional status, rather than the characteristic feature of Marasmus.

questions.text: Epstein Barr Virus is attributed to the pathogenesis of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection, particularly in endemic regions such as southern China, parts of Africa, and among the Inuit population of the Arctic.
  • EBV has a significant role in the development of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, as confirmed by the virus's consistent presence in tumor cells worldwide where NPC occurs. Patients affected by NPC exhibit consistently elevated antibody titers to viral capsid antigens, which indicates recent or active EBV infection.
  • The clonal structure of the viral genome within individual tumors suggests that EBV infection occurred before tumor development, implicating the virus in the pathogenesis of NPC. However, despite the universal presence of EBV in NPC cases worldwide, the tumor's restricted geographic distribution suggests that genetic or environmental cofactors also contribute to its development

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign tumor that primarily affects adolescent males. It arises from the vascular tissues in the back of the nasal cavity and nasopharynx. However, it is not caused by the Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV). The exact cause of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is unknown, but hormonal and genetic factors are believed to play a role.

Option C - Stewart's granuloma: Stewart's granuloma, also known as lobular capillary hemangioma or pyogenic granuloma, is a benign vascular tumor that can occur in various locations, including the nasal cavity and nasopharynx. It is not caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).

Option D - Rhinoscleroma: Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by the bacterium Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It primarily affects the nasal cavity and nasopharynx. It is not caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV). Rhinoscleroma is more commonly seen in regions with poor hygiene and sanitation.

questions.text: What is the treatment method that is most commonly recommended for a patient diagnosed with advanced nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Chemoradiotherapy:

  • The most preferred treatment modality for a patient with nasopharyngeal carcinoma depends on various factors, including the stage of the cancer, the extent of spread, the patient's overall health, and individual considerations.
  • However, in general, the preferred treatment approach for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is chemoradiotherapy.
  • This approach has shown the best outcomes for nasopharyngeal carcinoma patients. It helps to address both the primary tumor in the nasopharynx as well as any potential spread of cancer cells to nearby lymph nodes or distant sites.

Treatment for NPC based on stage:

  • Stages 1 and 2: Radiotherapy is curative
  • Stages 3 and 4: Chemo-radiotherapy
  • IMRT (Intensity modulated radiotherapy)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Surgical Excision: The main indication for surgical treatment is residual and recurrent tumors after radiotherapy or radio-chemotherapy, both in the nasopharynx and cervical lymph nodes. It can also be used for primary, limited, radio-resistant tumors. 

Option B - Radiotherapy: It can be used alone or in combination with other modalities like chemotherapy. Radiotherapy is particularly effective in the early stages.

Option C - Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is mainly used in combination with radiotherapy in advanced stages.

questions.text: A 20 year old female patient presented with throat pain and difficulty in swallowing. On examination, her right tonsil was found to be congested and uvula pushed to opposite side, left side tonsil was normal, what could be the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Quinsy

  • Quinsy, also known as peritonsillar abscess, shows the characteristic feature of severe pain in the throat, which is usually unilateral odynophagia that is difficult to swallow saliva. On examination, congested tonsils and uvula are pushed to the opposite side.
  • Quinsy is a complication of acute tonsillitis where pus accumulates between the tonsillar capsule and the surrounding tissue.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Retropharyngeal abscess; A retropharyngeal abscess is an infection that develops in the space located behind the pharynx. It is more commonly seen in children and typically presents with symptoms such as high fever, severe neck pain, difficulty swallowing, and a stiff neck. In the given scenario, the symptoms and examination findings do not suggest a retropharyngeal abscess.

Option B: Acute parenchymatous tonsillitis; refers to inflammation and infection of the tonsils. It typically presents with symptoms such as sore throat, difficulty swallowing, fever, and enlarged and erythematous tonsils. However, the described examination findings of congested right tonsil and the pushing of the uvula to the opposite side are more indicative of a localized abscess, specifically quinsy, rather than generalized tonsillitis.

Option D: Parapharyngeal abscess; A parapharyngeal abscess is an infection that develops in the space adjacent to the pharynx, located between the pharyngeal muscles and the deep neck fascia. It can cause symptoms such as severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, neck pain, and swelling in the neck. However, the presented scenario describes findings consistent with a peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) rather than a parapharyngeal abscess.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of Meniere's disease?

choices.text: Radiofrequency ablation is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Radiofrequency ablation is the treatment of choice:

  • Meniere's disease is typically managed with a combination of lifestyle changes, medications to control symptoms like vertigo and nausea, and in some cases, surgical interventions. Radiofrequency ablation is not commonly used as a treatment for Meniere's disease. Instead, treatments such as diuretics, vestibular rehabilitation therapy, and in severe cases, procedures like endolymphatic sac decompression or vestibular nerve section may be considered.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Low frequency sensorineural hearing loss:

  • One of the hallmark characteristics of Meniere's disease is fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, typically affecting low frequencies initially. This means that hearing loss primarily occurs in the lower pitches, such as those of deep voices or low musical notes. Over time, this hearing loss may progress and involve higher frequencies as well.

Option B- Idiopathic:

  • Primary Meniere's disease is considered idiopathic, meaning its exact cause is unknown. While there are several theories about its origin, such as fluid imbalance in the inner ear or problems with the endolymphatic sac, the precise cause remains unclear. Diagnosis is typically based on a combination of symptoms, including recurrent vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus (ringing in the ears), and a feeling of fullness or pressure in the ear.

Option C- Endolymphatic pathology:

  • Endolymphatic hydrops, which refers to an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the inner ear's endolymphatic system, is a commonly proposed pathological mechanism underlying Meniere's disease. While the exact cause of endolymphatic hydrops is not fully understood, it is believed to contribute to the development of Meniere's disease in many cases.

questions.text: Which cartilage is responsible for the protrusion of the Adam's apple?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Thyroid

  • The protrusion of the Adam's apple, also known as the laryngeal prominence, is primarily due to the cartilage known as the thyroid cartilage.
  • The thyroid cartilage is the largest cartilage of the larynx and forms the front part of the laryngeal skeleton.
  • In males, it tends to be more prominent, giving rise to the visible Adam's apple.
  • Unpaired/ Hyaline
  • Ala (2 ALA of single cartilage)
    • 90 in males
    • 120 in females
  • Oblique line of thyroid cartilage gives attachment to
    • Sternum to thyroid: Sternothyroid muscle
    • Thyroid to hyoid: Thyrohyoid
    • Thyroid to pharynx: Thyropharyngus
  • Thyroid cartilage gives attachment to
    • Epiglottis: Above
    • Vocal cords: Below

Incorrect options:

Option B: The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped cartilage located below the thyroid cartilage in the larynx. It forms the base of the larynx and provides support to the vocal cords. The cricoid cartilage does not contribute to the protrusion of the Adam's apple.

Option C: Hyoid; The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located in the neck, above the larynx. It serves as a point of attachment for various muscles and ligaments in the neck and plays a role in swallowing and speech. However, it is not directly associated with the protrusion of the Adam's apple.

questions.text: Which of the following is implicated as the cause of office headaches?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Frontal sinusitis:

  • Usually, the pain of frontal sinusitis is localized over the affected sinus and has characteristic periodicity, which comes up on waking, increases gradually and reaches its peak by about mid-day and then starts subsiding.
  • So it is also known as an “office headache” due to its presence only during office hours.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B and D are not implicated in causing pain in the forehead and, hence, do not cause office headaches.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most constant and largest ethmoidal air cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bulla ethmoidalis:

  • The most constant and largest ethmoidal air cells are bulla ethmoidal.
  • It is situated behind the uncinate process.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Agger nasi cell:

  • This tiny anterior ethmoidal air cell is located next to the frontonasal recess in the anterior section of the ethmoid sinus. 
  • The Agger Nasi is the anterior most or the 1st ethmoid air cell.

Option C - Haller cell:

  • If there is an air cell present on the floor of the orbit, then the cell is known as the Haller cell.
  • A Haller cell can be anterior or posterior.
  • If there is an ethmoidal air cell that is inferomedial to the orbit, it is the Haller cell.

Option D - Onodi cell:

  • The Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal air cell that extends into the sphenoid sinus in the posterior and lateral directions.
  • Sometimes, these cells may have an optic nerve within them.
  • Sometimes, it may also contain Internal Carotid Artery.

questions.text: A patient with Pink color skin & mucosa, a bitter almond smell from breath, and frothy discharge. The cause of death is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - HCN poisoning:

  • HCN or Hydrogen Cyanide is a pale-blue or almost colorless gas or liquid with a bitter almond taste.

  • When it interferes with using oxygen in the human body, it directly affects our blood vessels, heart, brain, and lungs.

  • Additionally, the pink color of mucosa and skin appears because of the excessive infectious hemoglobin saturation.

  • Symptoms of HCN poisoning:

    • Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath

    • Rapid and shallow breathing

    • Rapid heart rate (tachycardia)

    • Chest pain or tightness

    • Dizziness or lightheadedness

    • Headache

    • Confusion or disorientation

    • Seizures or convulsions

    • Loss of consciousness

    • Nausea and vomiting

    • Abdominal pain or cramps

    • Skin discoloration (bluish appearance)

    • Eye irritation or redness (if exposed to HCN gas)

    • Cyanide-like odor (bitter almond odor) may be present in some cases

  • Treatment:

    •  Activated charcoal to absorb the toxin.

    • In severe cases, Cyanokit, hydroxocobalamin, and Eli lilly's antidote

Incorrect Options:

Option A - H2S poisoning: H2S poisoning is also a severe and fatal condition. The primary symptoms of this condition are headaches, tremors, nausea, delirium, convulsions, disturbed equilibrium, eye and skin irritation, rapid unconsciousness, and eventually death.

Option B - CO poisoning: CO poisoning can also be deadly. The most common signs of CO poisoning are vomiting, upset stomach, dizziness, headache, chest pain, and confusion. If anyone inhales excessive CO, it has the potential to kill that individual.

Option D - OPC poisoning: OPC poisoning is a known class of insecticides that occurs when a person is exposed to organophosphates. The condition's primary symptoms are a runny nose, glassy eyes, blurry vision, agitation, muscle weakness, narrowed pill, etc. In severe cases, it leads to coma or collapse.

questions.text: What is the ideal investigation of choice for confirming CSF rhinorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Beta 2 transferrin analysis:

  • The most appropriate investigation to confirm cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea is Beta 2 transferrin analysis
  • Beta 2 transferrin is a specific marker for cerebrospinal fluid. Beta 2 transferrin is a glycoprotein found in high concentrations in the cerebrospinal fluid. It is not found in mucus or saliva. Testing the fluid obtained from the nasal discharge for the presence of beta 2 transferrin can confirm the presence of CSF rhinorrhea. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - CT-cisternogram: CT-cisternogram is a specialized imaging technique that can be used to detect CSF leaks. It involves injecting a contrast dye into the spinal fluid and then performing a CT scan to visualize the flow of the contrast material. While it is a useful diagnostic tool, it is more invasive and typically not the first-line investigation for suspected CSF rhinorrhea.

Option C - Nasal endoscopy: Nasal endoscopy can identify the site of CSF leakage and is useful for evaluating the nasal passages and sinus openings. However, it does not directly confirm the presence of CSF in the nasal discharge.

Option D - MRI with contrast: MRI with contrast can help visualize structures in the nasal and sinus region, but it may not always clearly show the presence of CSF leakage. Additionally, it is not specific for confirming CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: Which  poisoning is caused by a bullet retained inside the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lead:

  • Lead poisoning can occur due to a bullet in an individual's body.

  • The poisoning generally occurs when the bullet lead reaches in the synovial cavity of the chest, hip, and pleural space.

  • The clinical features of lead poisoning are :

    • A - Anemia

    • B -Basophilic stippling, Burtonian line.

    • C -Colic and constipation.

    • D - Drops (wrist drop).

    • E - Encephalopathy, common in toddlers.

    • F - Facial pallor (earliest and most consistent sign).

    • G - Gout (decreases uric acid excretion).

  • Lab Investigation:

    • Search for polycythemia, anemia, anisocytosis, eosinophilia, poikilocytosis, and punctuate basophilia in the peripheral smear.

    • In the lab investigation, the blood sample shows increased levels of lead and erythrocyte porphyrin. The urine samples show increased coproporphyrinogen, ALA, and erythrocyte porphyrin. On the radiology tests, the expert finds bone lines, the presence of lead chips, total quantity of lead present in the body.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Iron:

  • Iron poisoning mostly happens due to consuming iron supplements. Therefore, it is best to take advice from a healthcare professional regarding dosage.

Option B - Phosphorus:

  • Phosphorus is very dangerous for our body, but the retained bullet cannot be the cause of phosphorus poisoning.

  • The primary reasons for Phosphorus poisoning are tumor lysis syndrome, rhabdomyolysis, and impaired renal function.

Option C - Nitrocellulose:

  • When an individual inhales Nitrocellulose, it can cause Nitro cellulose poisoning. So, it is one of the incorrect choices.

questions.text: What could be the diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who was involved in a road traffic accident, did not wear a helmet, experienced a brief loss of consciousness, and later presented to the ENT department with complaints of clear fluid discharge from her nose after 2 days?

choices.text: Infection due to hemosinus because of RTA

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CSF rhinorrhea:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this case would be CSF (cerebrospinal fluid) rhinorrhea.
  • CSF rhinorrhea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid from the nose due to a fracture or injury to the skull base.
  • The history of a road traffic accident, loss of consciousness, and the subsequent clear fluid discharge from the nose are consistent with CSF rhinorrhea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Allergic rhinitis: Allergic rhinitis is characterized by inflammation of the nasal passages, sneezing, itching, and nasal congestion. It is not typically associated with a trauma or injury.

Option B - Infection due to hemosinus because of RTA: While an infection can occur as a complication of a fracture or injury to the sinus caused by a road traffic accident (RTA), the immediate clear fluid discharge from the nose suggests CSF leakage rather than an infection.

Option D - Post-traumatic rhinitis: Clear fluid discharge from the nose, especially following a head injury and loss of consciousness, is more indicative of CSF rhinorrhea than post-traumatic rhinitis.

questions.text: In an autopsy of suspected poisoning, which organ, along with the stomach, part of the intestine, and liver, is preserved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Kidney:

  • In an autopsy of suspected poisoning, the kidney is preserved because it is the primary organ responsible for filtering and excreting toxins from the body. The kidney can provide crucial evidence of poisoning.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lungs: While the lungs may show signs of poisoning in some instances, they are not typically preserved as a routine procedure in a poisoning autopsy.

Option C - Brain: The brain is not directly involved in the filtration or detoxifying of toxins, so it is not commonly preserved in a poisoning autopsy.

Option D - Heart: The heart's primary function is to pump blood and distribute oxygen, so it is not explicitly preserved in a poisoning autopsy unless there is suspicion of cardiac involvement.

questions.text: In the case of a man who arrived at the emergency department with a head injury resulting from a vehicle accident, the preferred diagnostic test is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - NCCT (Non-Contrast CT):

  • Non-Contrast Computed Tomography scans are widely used in the emergency department to evaluate head injuries.
  • CT scans provide detailed images of the skull, brain, and surrounding structures, allowing for the detection of skull fractures, intracranial bleeding (hemorrhage), and other traumatic brain injuries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CECT: While CECT can be helpful in certain situations, such as evaluating vascular abnormalities or tumors, it is not the initial investigation of choice for a head injury.

Option B - MRI: MRI scans take longer to perform and may not be readily available in emergency settings. In the acute phase of a head injury, an NCCT scan is usually the preferred initial investigation.

Option D - X-ray: While X-ray can be useful in certain scenarios, it is not the investigation of choice for evaluating head injuries.

questions.text: During the examination of injury, hair bulbs are noted to be crushed. The probable type of wound is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Laceration:

  • Laceration involves the tearing or cutting of tissues, which can crush the underlying hair bulbs.

  • It often results from blunt force trauma, which can cause compression and crushing of the hair bulbs.

  • Crushed hair bulbs indicate a significant force applied to the area, consistent with a laceration.

Characteristics of Lacerations:

  • Trauma: Blunt trauma, may be heavy

  • Damage: 3-Dimensional injury

  • Margins: Irregular

  • Floor: Vessels, nerve, and hair bulb are crushed.

  • Structures: Epidermis +dermis + subcutaneous tissue.

  • Swallow tail, tearing at the end, diverging.

  • Tissue bridges and tissue fragments connect each other from the margin.

  • Bleeding comparatively due to crushed blood vessels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Abrasions: Abrasions typically involve superficial damage to the skin without significant underlying tissue injury. They do not usually cause crushing of hair bulbs.

Option C - Stab injuries: Stab injuries are caused by a pointed object piercing the skin. While they may cause damage to the underlying tissues, they do not typically result in crushed hair bulbs.

Option D - None: This option is incorrect because the description in the question indicates a specific type of wound characterized by crushed hair bulbs corresponding to a laceration.

questions.text: In a 32-year-old male, who complained of fever and pain in the upper right abdomen following meals, the recommended diagnostic test is
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - USG:

  • Based on the symptoms of fever and pain in the right upper hypochondrium after food intake, the probable diagnosis is cholecystitis or gallstones.

  • Cholecystitis refers to inflammation of the gallbladder, which is commonly caused by gallstones obstructing the cystic duct.

  • The symptoms are often precipitated or worsened by food intake, particularly fatty meals.

  • USG is the initial investigation of choice for evaluating the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, including the liver, gallbladder, and biliary system.

  • USG is non-invasive, widely available, cost-effective, and does not involve exposure to ionizing radiation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): While CECT can provide detailed imaging of the abdominal organs, it is not the investigation of choice as the initial step in this scenario. USG is preferred as it is a safer and more readily available option for evaluating gallbladder and biliary pathology.

Option C - MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): MRI can provide detailed imaging of the abdominal organs without radiation exposure, but it is usually not the initial investigation for suspected cholecystitis or gallstones. MRI may be reserved for specific indications or if further characterization of the findings from USG is required.

Option D - HRCT (High-Resolution Computed Tomography): HRCT is primarily used for evaluating lung parenchymal and interstitial lung diseases. It is not the investigation of choice for assessing the gallbladder or biliary system in this scenario.

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a 40-year-old patient presenting with a femur fracture accompanied by pulmonary infiltration and respiratory distress?
questions.solution:
Option A - Fat embolism

  • In the given scenario the probable diagnosis is fat embolism.
  • Fat embolism occurs when fat globules enter the bloodstream and block small blood vessels in various organs, including the lungs.
  • It commonly occurs after long bone fractures, such as femur fractures.
  • The fat globules can travel to the lungs and cause respiratory distress, pulmonary infiltration (seen on imaging), and other systemic manifestations.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pulmonary embolism: While pulmonary embolism can cause respiratory distress, it is not directly associated with femur fractures unless there is concurrent deep vein thrombosis.

Option C - Air embolism: While air embolism can cause respiratory distress, it is less likely to be associated with a femur fracture.

Option D - Obstruction: The term "obstruction" is broad and does not specify a particular condition.

questions.text: Anthracosis is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-Coal Dust :

  • Anthracosis, also known as coal dust deposition, is a lung condition caused by the inhalation and deposition of coal dust particles in the lungs. It commonly affects individuals who are exposed to coal dust over a prolonged period, such as coal miners, workers in coal-fired industries, and individuals living in areas with high levels of coal dust pollution.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option a. Silica:. Prolonged inhalation of silica dust can lead to a lung disease called silicosis..

Option c. Asbestos:. Inhalation of asbestos fibers can cause lung diseases, including asbestosis and mesothelioma. Anthracosis is unrelated to asbestos exposure.

Option d. Sugar cane: Individuals working in the sugar cane industry may be exposed to other respiratory hazards, such as dust and mold, which can lead to respiratory conditions.

questions.text: Which is the recommended chemoprophylaxis for an individual traveling to a region endemic for malaria?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Chloroquine

  • When traveling to an endemic malaria region, chemoprophylaxis is essential to prevent the development of malaria.
  • Chemoprophylaxis refers to the use of specific medications to suppress the growth of the malarial parasite in the body.
  • Chloroquine is the chemoprophylaxis of choice for regions where Plasmodium falciparum, the most severe form of malaria, is still sensitive to this medication.
  • Chloroquine works by inhibiting the growth and replication of the malaria parasite within the red blood cells.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Lumefantrine- Lumefantrine is an antimalarial medication used for the treatment of malaria, particularly in combination with artemisinin-based drugs. It is not typically used for chemoprophylaxis.

Option B: Pyrimethamine- Pyrimethamine is an antiparasitic medication used in the treatment of malaria, particularly in combination with sulfadoxine (Fansidar). It is not commonly used for chemoprophylaxis.

Option D: Quinine- Quinine is an antimalarial medication that was previously used as a first-line treatment for malaria. However, it is no longer recommended for chemoprophylaxis due to concerns about its effectiveness and the development of resistance.

questions.text: Thimble bladder is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chronic TB:

  • Thimble bladder is a term used to describe a condition in which the bladder becomes small, contracted, and thickened due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis.

  • It is typically seen in chronic tuberculosis (TB) of the bladder.

  • The chronic inflammation causes fibrosis and contraction of the bladder, resulting in its characteristic appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Acute TB: Acute TB refers to an active and progressive infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. While TB can affect various organs, including the lungs, lymph nodes, and kidneys, it is less commonly associated with acute bladder involvement. Therefore, acute TB is not typically associated with a thimble bladder.

Options C - Neurogenic bladder: Neurogenic bladder is defined as bladder dysfunction resulting from a central or peripheral neurologic insult. Possible symptoms include urinary incontinence, urgency, nocturia, straining, incomplete voiding, and urinary retention.

Options D - Schistosomiasis: Schistosomiasis is a parasitic infection caused by Schistosoma species. While schistosomiasis can affect the urinary system, causing inflammation and fibrosis, it does not commonly result in the characteristic thimble bladder appearance. Schistosomiasis-associated bladder abnormalities usually manifest as thickening, calcifications, and bladder wall irregularities.

questions.text: What triad is characterized by abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Charcot’s triad:

  • In the given scenario of a patient presenting with abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice, the triad commonly associated with these symptoms is Charcot's triad.
  • Charcot's triad is indicative of a condition affecting the biliary system, such as obstruction of the bile ducts due to gallstones or other causes.
  • Charcot's Triad: Charcot's triad is a clinical term used to describe a combination of symptoms associated with acute cholangitis, which is inflammation of the bile ducts. The classic triad consists of:
    • Abdominal pain: Typically located in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, it can be severe and colicky in nature.
    • Fever: Often accompanied by chills and rigors.
    • Jaundice: Yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated levels of bilirubin in the bloodstream.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Saint Triad: Saint's triad comprises the simultaneous occurrence of the following medical conditions: gallstones (cholelithiasis), hiatal hernia, and diverticular disease (diverticulosis of the colon).

Option C - Virchow Triad: The Virchow triad consists of blood stasis, endothelial injury, and hypercoagulability.

Option D - Reynold's Pentad: Reynold's pentad is characterized by Charcot's triad alongside shock and alterations in mental status.

questions.text: What methods would you employ to identify Vitamin A Deficiency in a school setting?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B. 

  • Screening for Vitamin A deficiency in a school setting can be done through the identification of clinical signs and symptoms associated with the deficiency. One of the early signs of Vitamin A deficiency is night blindness, which refers to the inability or difficulty to see in low light conditions or at night. Night blindness occurs due to the impaired functioning of the retina, which is responsible for vision in dim light.
  • By asking individuals, particularly school children, about their ability to see in low light conditions or at night, healthcare providers or school health personnel can screen for the presence of night blindness. Children who report difficulties with night vision are likely to have an underlying Vitamin A deficiency.

Incorrect Options

Option A. Retinol: Retinol is a form of Vitamin A, but it is not a specific screening method for Vitamin A deficiency. Retinol levels can be measured in blood samples to assess overall Vitamin A status, but this is not typically used as a screening tool in a school setting.

Option C. Carotene: Carotene, a precursor to Vitamin A, can be found in certain foods such as carrots, sweet potatoes, and leafy greens. However, assessing carotene levels is not a practical screening method for Vitamin A deficiency in a school setting.

Option D. Bitot spots: Bitot spots are a clinical manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency and appear as foamy, white patches on the conjunctiva of the eye. While the presence of Bitot spots may indicate Vitamin A deficiency, their detection requires a close examination of the eyes, which may not be feasible in a school screening scenarioC

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with breast enlargement and tenderness without a substance abuse history. Examination shows visibly enlarged breasts with palpable tissue beneath the nipples. What is the least likely cause of his gynecomastia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Prostate cancer:

  • Prostate cancer is a malignant tumor that develops in the prostate gland. Although hormonal imbalances can occur in advanced prostate cancer, gynecomastia is not a common manifestation of this condition.
  • The growth of prostate cancer is primarily driven by testosterone, and gynecomastia is more commonly associated with an imbalance between estrogen and testosterone levels. Therefore, gynecomastia is not typically seen in prostate cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Klinefelter syndrome: This condition often leads to lower testosterone production and an imbalance between estrogen and testosterone, resulting in gynecomastia. 

Option B - Liver cirrhosis:  In cirrhosis, the liver's ability to metabolize hormones, including estrogen, is affected. This can lead to an imbalance between estrogen and testosterone, resulting in gynecomastia. 

Option C - Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism might be associated with gynecomastia

questions.text: Completed family size depends on
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C.

  • The completed family size refers to the total number of children born to a woman or a couple throughout their reproductive years. It is a measure that reflects the fertility or childbearing pattern of a population or an individual.
  • The number of children is a key determinant of completed family size. As each child is born, it contributes to the overall size of the family. Therefore, the more children a couple or a woman has, the larger their completed family size will be.

Incorrect Options

Option A. Number of adolescents: The number of adolescents in a family does not directly determine the completed family size. Adolescents refer to individuals who are in the transitional phase between childhood and adulthood, and their presence alone does not impact the total number of children born.

Option B. Number of women: The number of women alone does not determine the completed family size. While the reproductive choices and behaviors of women contribute to the overall fertility of a population, it is the actual number of children born that reflects the completed family size.

Option D. Number of persons: The total number of persons in a family includes individuals of all ages, including children, adolescents, and adults. While the size of the family affects various aspects of family dynamics, the completed family size specifically focuses on the number of children.

questions.text: Yellow fever vaccine is valid for
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: Life long

Yellow fever vaccine is a highly effective vaccine that provides long-lasting immunity against yellow fever virus. Once a person receives the recommended dose of the vaccine, they are considered protected for life and do not require additional booster doses. This is why option B, which states "lifelong," is the correct answer.

Incorrect Options

Option A, C & D are wrong

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 28-year-old patient who is an alcoholic and presents to the hospital with symptoms of frequent vomiting, chest pain, fever, and hydropneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Boerrhave syndrome:

  • In the given scenario of a 28-year-old alcoholic patient presenting with binge vomiting, chest pain, fever, and hydropneumothorax, the probable diagnosis is Boerrhave syndrome.
  • Boerrhave Syndrome also known as spontaneous esophageal rupture, is a rare but life-threatening condition characterized by a full-thickness tear or rupture of the esophagus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tension Pneumothorax: it is not directly related to the binge vomiting and hydropneumothorax in this scenario.

Option C - PUD Perforation: it is not directly associated with the symptoms of binge vomiting, chest pain, and hydropneumothorax described in the scenario.

Option D - Mallory Weiss Tear: it can cause upper gastrointestinal bleeding, it is not typically associated with chest pain, fever, or hydropneumothorax.

questions.text: In the event of an accident, prompt action should be taken in the initial management following the arrival of the medical team. Excluding
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Check BP:

  • In an accident case, the early management after the medical team's arrival involves various critical steps to ensure the patient's stabilization and assessment
  • While monitoring blood pressure is crucial in the overall management of trauma patients, it is not typically considered an immediate priority in the early stages of patient care. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stabilization of cervical vertebrae: Stabilization of cervical vertebrae is an essential step in managing trauma patients, especially those involved in accidents. It involves immobilizing the neck and spine to prevent further injury and potential damage to the spinal cord.

Option C - Check respiration Check respiration is an important step in the initial management of trauma patients. Assessing the patient's breathing pattern, rate, and adequacy is crucial to identify any potential airway compromise or respiratory distress.

Option D - GCS score: GCS score refers to the Glasgow Coma Scale, which is used to assess the level of consciousness and neurological status of the patient. Evaluating the patient's GCS score helps determine the severity of brain injury and guides subsequent management decisions.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown below
questions.solution:
Option D - Port wine stain:

  • The condition shown in the image is a port wine stain.
  • Port wine stain, also known as capillary malformation or nevus flammeus, is a type of vascular birthmark that appears as a pink, red, or purple discoloration on the skin.
  • It is typically present at birth and persists throughout life.
  • Port wine stains are caused by abnormal development of blood vessels near the surface of the skin.
  • They can occur anywhere on the body but are most commonly found on the face, neck, or upper extremities.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Strawberry Hemangioma: This vascular birthmark, also called a strawberry stain, manifests as a raised, red or purplish lesion on the skin. Typically present at birth or in the first weeks of life, it grows rapidly initially and gradually fades over time, unlike a port wine stain.

Option B - Erythema Multiforme: Characterized by distinctive target-like skin lesions, erythema multiforme features a central red spot surrounded by a pale ring and an outer red ring. Triggers can include infections, medications, and allergic reactions.

Option C - Roseola Infantum: Also known as sixth disease or erythema subitum, this viral infection commonly affects infants and young children. It begins with a sudden high fever followed by the development of a rash.

questions.text: All are components of Kuppuswamy scale
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option D: Income, Occupation, Education

  • The Kuppuswamy scale is a widely used socioeconomic scale in India that assesses the social and economic status of individuals or families. It helps in categorizing individuals into different socioeconomic classes based on their income, occupation, and education level.
  • Income, Occupation, Education: This option correctly identifies the components of the Kuppuswamy scale. Income refers to the individual's or family's earnings, occupation represents the type of work or profession, and education indicates the level of formal education attained.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Income, Housing, Education- While income and education are included in the Kuppuswamy scale, housing is not one of its components. Housing is an important indicator of socioeconomic status, but it is not specifically considered in the Kuppuswamy scale.

Option B: Income, Livestock, Housing- Livestock is not one of the components of the Kuppuswamy scale. The scale primarily focuses on income, occupation, and education as indicators of socioeconomic status.

Option C: Housing, Livestock, Land- Similarly, livestock and land are not components of the Kuppuswamy scale. These factors may be relevant in assessing socioeconomic status in other contexts, but they are not included in the Kuppuswamy scale.

questions.text: What could be the possible cause of sweating and diarrhea occurring within 20 minutes of eating in a patient who has undergone gastrectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Early Dumping syndrome:

  • Dumping syndrome is a condition that can occur after gastrectomy, a surgical procedure where a part or the entire stomach is removed.
  • It is characterized by a rapid emptying of the stomach contents into the small intestine, leading to various symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Late dumbing syndrome: Late dumping syndrome occurs 1 to 3 hours after a meal and is characterized by symptoms like weakness, lightheadedness, sweating, and palpitations due to reactive hypoglycemia.

Option C - Hyperglycemia: it can cause symptoms such as increased thirst, frequent urination, and fatigue, it is not typically associated with sweating and diarrhea after eating.

Option D -Hypoglycemia: Hypoglycemia may occur as a result of excessive insulin release during the early dumping syndrome, but the predominant symptoms in this case are sweating and diarrhea.

questions.text: Most sensitive test for microfilariae
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Membrane filter concentration technique

  • Microfilariae are the larval stage of filarial parasites that circulate in the blood of infected individuals. Detecting microfilariae is crucial for diagnosing filariasis.
  • The membrane filter concentration technique is considered the most sensitive test for detecting microfilariae.
  • This method involves filtering a large volume of blood through a membrane filter, which captures the microfilariae. The filter is then examined under a microscope to identify and count the microfilariae accurately.

Incorrect Options

Option A: DEC challenge test- The DEC challenge test involves examining blood samples for the presence of microfilariae. While this test can be useful, it is not the most sensitive method for detecting microfilariae.

Option B: Immunofluorescence test- While immunofluorescence can be employed to detect microfilariae, it may not be as sensitive as the membrane filter concentration technique.

Option D: Thick films- Thick films are commonly used for the diagnosis of malaria, not specifically for microfilariae.

questions.text: A 6 months child presented with the following presentation. What is the management protocol?

choices.text: Indication of surgery if not resolved by 2 years

questions.solution:
Correct Option B -Surgery after 5 year:

  • In the given clinical scenario a 6-month-old child presents with an image suggestive of umbilical hernia.
  • Umbilical hernias in infants often resolve on their own without any intervention by the age of 2 years but persistence beyond 5 years is an indication of surgery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Indication of surgery if not resolved by 2 years:

  • Indication of surgery if not resolved by 2 years is not right as surgery is indicated after 5 yr age

Option C -Immediate surgery:

  • Immediate surgery, is incorrect for uncomplicated umbilical hernias in infants.

Option D - Hernioplasty:

  • Hernioplasty is a surgical technique used to repair hernias.

questions.text: What is the recommended initial investigation for genital tuberculosis?

choices.text: Urine sample for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) culture
Genital swab for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing

questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Genital swab for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing

Explanation of options:

  1. Endometrial biopsy: While endometrial biopsy can be useful in diagnosing genital TB, it is an invasive procedure and may not be the first-line investigation. Endometrial biopsy is typically considered when other less invasive tests, such as PCR testing, have not provided a conclusive diagnosis or when there is a strong clinical suspicion of genital TB.

  2. Urine sample for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) culture: Urine sample for AFB culture is essential in diagnosing genitourinary TB, but it may not be the early investigation of choice for genital TB. Genitourinary TB can involve the kidneys, bladder, and ureters, leading to the presence of mycobacteria in the urine. However, when specifically investigating for genital TB, other tests like PCR are more targeted and less invasive.

  3. Genital swab for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing: This is the correct option. PCR testing is a sensitive and specific method to detect the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA in genital samples. PCR testing allows for the rapid identification of TB infection in the genital tract and can be an early investigation of choice. It is less invasive compared to procedures like endometrial biopsy and provides a targeted approach to diagnosing genital TB.

  4. Chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray is useful for diagnosing pulmonary TB (TB affecting the lungs), it may not be the primary investigation for genital TB. Genital TB is a specific form of extrapulmonary TB, and although pulmonary TB can be associated with genital TB, direct investigation of the genital tract is needed for a definitive diagnosis.

  • Endometrial biopsy involves obtaining a tissue sample from the lining of the uterus (endometrium) for pathological examination.
  • In cases of suspected genital TB, endometrial biopsy can reveal granulomatous inflammation, caseating necrosis, or acid-fast bacilli, which are indicative of TB infection.
  • It provides direct evidence of TB involvement in the genital tract.

questions.text: Vaccination & Mass chemoprophylaxis represent
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Specific protection:

  • Includes vaccination and mass chemoprophylaxis.
  • Directly targets specific diseases to prevent occurrence.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Health promotion: Encourages overall well-being.

Option C - Early diagnosis and treatment: Focuses on timely medical intervention.

Option D - Rehabilitation: Aims to restore functional abilities post-illness.

questions.text: Cellulitis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Suprative & Invasive:

  • Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection characterized by inflammation of the skin and underlying tissues. 

  • Cellulitis is considered suppurative because it often involves the formation of pus, which consists of dead white blood cells, bacteria, and tissue debris. It is invasive because the bacterial infection penetrates and spreads through the deeper layers of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, causing inflammation and damage beyond the surface layer. This invasion can lead to significant tissue destruction and systemic complications if not promptly treated with antibiotics and proper wound care.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nonsuppurative & Noninvasive: Stating cellulitis as nonsuppurative and noninvasive, is incorrect. Cellulitis is typically associated with the presence of pus (suppuration) due to bacterial infection, and it can involve deeper layers of the skin and tissues (invasive).

Option B - Nonsuppurative & invasive: Stating cellulitis as nonsuppurative and invasive, is also incorrect. While cellulitis can be invasive, it is commonly associated with the presence of pus (suppuration) as bacteria invade and cause an inflammatory response in the affected area.

Option C - Suprative & Noninvasive: Stating cellulitis as suppurative and noninvasive, is incorrect as well. Cellulitis often involves the production of pus (suppuration) due to bacterial infection, and it can extend into deeper tissues (invasive).

questions.text: What is the relationship between incidence and prevalence in a disease with 100% mortality rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- P < I:

  • Incidence and prevalence are important epidemiological measures.
  • Incidence refers to new cases of a disease within a specific time period.
  • Prevalence refers to total existing cases of a disease at a specific point in time.
  • In a disease with 100% mortality, incidence is always greater than prevalence.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- P = I: Incorrect as prevalence is usually lower than incidence in diseases with 100% mortality.

Option C - P > I: Incorrect as prevalence is typically lower than incidence in such diseases.

Option D - No relationship between both: Incorrect as there is a clear relationship between incidence and prevalence in this scenario.

questions.text: Prostate cancer most commonly seen in which zone:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Peripheral zone:

  • Prostate cancer most commonly originates in the peripheral zone of the prostate gland

  • The peripheral zone constitutes the outer part of the prostate and is where about 70-80% of prostate cancers arise.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Central zone: Prostate cancer is less frequently seen in the central zone of the prostate. The central zone comprises about 5-10% of the prostate gland and is located near the ejaculatory ducts.

Option B - Transition zone: Prostate cancer is less commonly observed in the transition zone as well. The transition zone surrounds the urethra and accounts for approximately 10-20% of the prostate gland. Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a non-cancerous condition, is more commonly found in this zone.

Option D - Anterior fibromuscular stroma: Prostate cancer does not typically arise in the anterior fibromuscular stroma. The anterior fibromuscular stroma is a non-glandular tissue in the prostate that provides structural support.

questions.text: SARS is caused by novel variant of
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B.

  • SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) is caused by a novel variant of the coronavirus. Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that can cause illnesses ranging from the common cold to more severe diseases such as SARS and COVID-19.
  • Coronaviruses have a characteristic structure with spike-like projections on their surface.

Incorrect Options

Option A. Lyssavirus, on the other hand, belongs to the family Rhabdoviridae and is the causative agent of rabies.

Option C. Pox virus refers to a family of viruses that includes the variola virus, the causative agent of smallpox.
