Option D. Toga virus refers to a family of viruses that includes the alphaviruses and flaviviruses, but they are not associated with SARS.

questions.text: The distal ileum was removed from a 20-year-old girl. Which absorption deficiency will be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Bile salts:

  • The distal ileum plays a crucial role in the absorption of bile salts, which are essential for the digestion and absorption of dietary fats.
  • Without the distal ileum, there can be impaired absorption of bile salts, leading to difficulties in fat digestion and subsequent deficiencies of fat-soluble vitamins, such as vitamins A, D, E, and K.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Iron: Iron absorption primarily occurs in the duodenum.

Option B - Folic acid: Folic acid, or folate, is absorbed in the upper small intestine, particularly in the duodenum and jejunum.

Option C - Copper: Copper absorption occurs primarily in the stomach and upper small intestine.

questions.text: In Disaster management, what is the term used when patients are classified based on their likelihood of survival?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Triage :

  • Triage involves assessing and categorizing patients based on the urgency of their medical needs and their chances of survival. The main objective of triage is to ensure that limited resources are allocated to those patients who are most in need and have the highest chances of survival. Patients are typically categorized into different triage categories, such as immediate, delayed, minimal, or expectant, depending on the severity of their injuries or illnesses.

Incorrect Options :

Option B: Tagging- Tagging refers to the process of identifying and labeling patients or individuals during a disaster or mass casualty incident.

Option C: Mitigation- Mitigation refers to measures taken to minimize or prevent the impact of disasters or reduce their severity.

Option D: Surge capacity- Surge capacity refers to the ability of healthcare systems to expand their resources and capabilities to accommodate a sudden influx of patients during a disaster or emergency.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for Esophageal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oxalate food:

  • While oxalate-rich foods can contribute to the formation of kidney stones in some individuals, they are not directly linked to the development of esophageal cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - GERD (Gastroesophageal reflux disease): Chronic reflux of stomach acid into the esophagus can lead to chronic inflammation, cellular damage, and an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

Option B - Betel chewing: Betel nuts contain carcinogenic substances, and the habit of chewing betel nuts is prevalent in certain regions, especially in South Asia.

Option D - Spicy food: The relationship between spicy food and esophageal carcinoma is not well-established.

questions.text: What type of anemia is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B12?
questions.solution:
Correct option

Option B. 

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to macrocytic hypochromic anemia. This type of anemia is characterized by red blood cells that are larger than normal (macrocytic) and have reduced hemoglobin content (hypochromic).
  • Vitamin B12 is essential for the production of healthy red blood cells. It plays a key role in the synthesis of DNA and in the maturation of red blood cells in the bone marrow.
  • Deficiency of vitamin B12 can result in ineffective DNA synthesis and impaired maturation of red blood cells, leading to the characteristic features of macrocytic hypochromic anemia.

Incorrect Options

Option A. Microcytic hypochromic anemia (choice A) is typically associated with iron deficiency anemia, where red blood cells are smaller and have reduced hemoglobin content.

Option C. Normocytic normochromic anemia (choice C) refers to anemia with normal-sized red blood cells and normal hemoglobin content. It can be caused by various factors such as chronic diseases, kidney problems, and bone marrow disorders.

Option D. None of the above is an incorrect answer as B is the correct answer

questions.text: The hospital received a patient with varicose veins, and an intern was on duty. Which test should the intern conduct to exclude the possibility of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Perthes test:

  • Perthes test can be used to rule out DVT

  • The Perthes test is a clinical test for assessing the patency of the deep femoral vein prior to varicose vein surgery.

Perthes test - Elastic bandage is applied in lower limb causing superficial vein obstruction

↓

Crampy pain after work or Exercise indicating deep vein obstruction

↓

DVT

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Brodie Tredelenberg test: The Trendelenburg test is used to determine the site of valvular incompetence in a patient with varicose veins.

Options C - Thomas test: The Thomas test is a test performed to assess hip flexion contracture and is not specific to ruling out DVT in a patient with varicose veins.

Options D - Ober test: The Ober test is used to assess tightness or contracture of the iliotibial band (ITB) and is unrelated to the diagnosis of DVT in a patient with varicose veins.

questions.text: Which is not a contraindication for OPV?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Diarrhoea:

  • Diarrhoea is not a contraindication for OPV. While it is generally recommended to administer vaccines when a child is healthy, mild diarrhoea does not pose a significant risk for administering OPV. However, if the diarrhoea is severe or accompanied by other signs of illness, it is advisable to delay vaccination until the child has recovered.
  • OPV, or oral polio vaccine, is an important vaccine used to protect against polio. It is administered orally and is effective in inducing immunity against poliovirus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Leukaemia- Individuals with leukaemia typically have compromised immune systems and may not mount an adequate immune response to the vaccine. Therefore, OPV is contraindicated.

Option C: Malignancy- Individuals with malignancy often have compromised immune systems due to their underlying condition or the treatments they are undergoing. Therefore, OPV is contraindicated.

Option D: Immunocompromised- Immunocompromised individuals have weakened immune systems and may not respond effectively to OPV.

questions.text: N95 respirator is used for
questions.solution:
Correct Option - Airborne precaution:

  • N95 respirators are a type of personal protective equipment (PPE) that is designed to provide a high level of respiratory protection.

  • N95 respirators are highly effective in filtering out airborne particles, including bacteria and viruses. They form a tight seal around the nose and mouth, filtering at least 95% of airborne particles when properly worn. This makes them suitable for use in healthcare settings when caring for patients with infectious respiratory diseases.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Droplet precautions: Surgical masks are typically used for droplet precautions.

Option C - Contact precautions: Gloves and gowns are typically used for contact precautions.

Option D - None of the above: It is wrong because Option B is the correct answer .

questions.text: Alvarado score of 2 is given for:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Tenderness in right lower quadrant:

  • The Alvarado score is a scoring system used in the assessment of suspected acute appendicitis.

  • It takes into account various clinical signs, symptoms, and laboratory findings to help evaluate the likelihood of appendicitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nausea: Only 1 point is given for nausea.

Option B - Temperature: The Alvarado score assigns 1 point for a elevated temperature.

Option D - Migratory pain: Only 1 point is given for Migratory pain

questions.text: Where will the left kidney transplant be positioned?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Iliac fossa:

  • During a left kidney transplantation, the transplanted kidney is typically placed in the iliac fossa.
  • The iliac fossa provides a suitable anatomical space for accommodating the transplanted kidney and connecting its blood vessels and ureter.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Kidney fossa: it does not accurately describe the placement of a transplanted kidney.

Option C - Retroperitoneal space: While the kidneys are naturally situated in the retroperitoneal space, during transplantation, the transplanted kidney is typically placed in the iliac fossa rather than the retroperitoneal space.

Option D - Hypogastric region: It is not the specific location where a left kidney transplantation would be placed.

questions.text: Rodent ulcer is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Basal cell cancer:

  • Rodent ulcer is used to describe basal cell cancer, which is a common type of skin cancer that arises from basal cells in the skin.

  • Rodent ulcer, also referred to as tear cancer, is characterized by local invasiveness, resulting in the destruction of surrounding tissues, typically seen on the face above the line connecting the ear lobule to the angle or corner of the mouth.

  • Emerging from the basal layer of the epidermis, it most frequently occurs on the nose, with inner canthus being another common site.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Squamous cell cancer: Squamous cell cancer, also known as squamous cell carcinoma, is a type of skin cancer that arises from squamous cells. It typically presents as a firm, red nodule or a flat lesion with a scaly or crusty surface. While squamous cell carcinoma is a common type of skin cancer, it is not specifically associated with the term "Rodent ulcer."

Option C - Rhinophyma: Rhinophyma is a condition characterized by the thickening and enlargement of the nose, often resulting in a bulbous or irregular appearance. It is typically associated with severe forms of rosacea and is not related to "Rodent ulcer," which specifically refers to a type of skin cancer.

Option D - Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma is a type of cancer that originates in glandular cells. It can occur in various organs, such as the lung, colon, breast, and prostate. However, it is not associated with the term "Rodent ulcer," which specifically refers to a type of skin cancer.

questions.text: Worms, bugs, parasites attached in the clothing’s of a person is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Contamination:

  • Contamination refers to the presence or introduction of harmful or undesirable substances onto an object or surface. In the context of the question, when worms, bugs, or parasites are attached to clothing, it indicates that the clothing has been contaminated with these organisms.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Infestation: 

  • It refers to the presence and reproduction of parasitic organisms on or within the body of a living host. It usually implies a heavy or prolonged presence of parasites, such as lice infestation or flea infestation.

Option C - Infection:

  • It refers to the invasion and multiplication of pathogenic microorganisms in the body, leading to disease or illness. It typically occurs when microorganisms enter the body through various routes, such as inhalation, ingestion, or direct contact.

Option D - Contagion:

  • It refers to the transmission or spread of infectious agents, such as bacteria or viruses, from one person to another. It implies the ability of the infectious agent to be transmitted between individuals.

questions.text: Target couple is

choices.text: Currently married couple where the wife is in reproductive age (15-49 yr. of age)
Eligible couples who have 2 – 3 living children

questions.solution:
Correct option B: Eligible couples who have 2 – 3 living children

  • Term target couples is applied to couples who have 2-3 living children or even newly married couples to make them accept the idea of family planning.

Incorrect Options

Option A.  "Currently married couple where the wife is in reproductive age (15-49 yr. of age)," is definition of eligible couple.

Option C. "Couple using contraception," refers to couples who are already using some form of contraception. While they are part of the target population for monitoring and evaluation of family planning services, the term "target couple" generally encompasses a broader group of couples who are eligible for family planning, including those not currently using contraception.

Option D. "Couple with 3 children," does not accurately capture the definition of a target couple. The number of children a couple has does not determine their eligibility or need for family planning services. Family planning aims to provide individuals and couples with the information, services, and methods to plan and space their pregnancies according to their desires and circumstances.

questions.text: 20 year old female previously diagnosed with Adenocarcinoma of the stomach, on examination following image was seen. What is the probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sister mary joseph nodule:

  • The given clinical image in a patient with adenocarcinoma stomach shows Sister Mary Joseph nodes.
  • The presence of cutaneous metastatic deposits around the umbilicus is referred to as Sister Mary Joseph nodes, which are not lymph nodes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Virchow's node: Virchow's node, also known as left supraclavicular lymph node enlargement, is often associated with metastatic cancer, particularly from the gastrointestinal tract or pelvic region. it is not specifically associated with the umbilicus, as seen in the image provided.

Option B - Irish node:It is thought to arise from intrathoracic metastatic spread of an intra-abdominal malignancy, particularly gastric cancer

Option D - Infected umbilical hernia: An infected hernia would typically present with signs of inflammation, such as redness, warmth, and tenderness, rather than a discrete nodule.

questions.text: Under Vision 2020, a disease that was added later in India
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Glaucoma:

  • Vision 2020: The Right to Sight is a global initiative launched by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness (IAPB) to eliminate avoidable blindness by the year 2020.
  • While glaucoma is a significant cause of blindness globally, it was added later in India's Vision 2020 initiative. This highlights the growing recognition of the importance of early detection, diagnosis, and treatment of glaucoma to prevent vision loss.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cataract: Cataract has been a significant focus of Vision 2020 from the beginning. Cataract is the leading cause of blindness worldwide, including in India. 

Option B - Childhood blindness: Childhood blindness has also been an important focus of Vision 2020.

Option D - Diabetic Retinopathy: Diabetic retinopathy is another eye condition that has been a focus of the Vision 2020 program.

questions.text: A lady with 50% TBSA burn + involvement of dermis & subcutaneous tissue came to the emergency department. Which degree burn is this:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 3rd degree:

  • A third-degree burn, also known as a full-thickness burn, involves the complete destruction of the epidermis and dermis and extends into the subcutaneous tissue. It typically appears as a white or charred area and is often painless due to the destruction of nerve endings. In the given scenario, with 50% total body surface area (TBSA) involvement and the inclusion of dermis and subcutaneous tissue, it is classified as a third-degree burn.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1st degree: A first-degree burn, also known as a superficial burn, only affects the outermost layer of the skin, the epidermis.

Option B - 2nd degree superficial: A 2nd-degree superficial burn, also called a partial-thickness burn, involves both the epidermis and a portion of the underlying dermis.

Option C - 2nd degree deep: A 2nd-degree deep burn, also a partial-thickness burn, affects the epidermis and extends deeper into the dermis, involving the deeper layers of the skin. It often presents with redness, pain, blistering, and severe swelling.

questions.text: Type of necrosis seen in brain is
questions.solution:
Option B - Liquefactive:

  • In the context of brain tissue, the type of necrosis seen is typically liquefactive necrosis.
  • Liquefactive necrosis is the predominant type of necrosis observed in the brain due to the presence of abundant water content and the breakdown of tissue by enzymes, resulting in the formation of cystic spaces filled with liquid debris.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Coagulative necrosis - Coagulative necrosis is characterized by the preservation of tissue architecture but with loss of cellular details. It is typically seen in organs such as the heart, kidney, and liver.

Option C - Fat necrosis - Fat necrosis occurs when there is damage to adipose tissue, resulting in the release of fatty acids and subsequent inflammation. It is commonly seen in conditions like acute pancreatitis or trauma to adipose-rich areas.

Option D - Fibrinoid necrosis: Fibrinoid necrosis is characterized by the deposition of fibrin-like material in the walls of blood vessels. It is typically associated with immune-mediated reactions, such as in certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: If the mother is found to be positive for HBsAg at 37 weeks of pregnancy, what is the recommended course of action for the baby?

choices.text: First HBIG then Hep B after 1 month

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hep B vaccine + HBIG:

  • The recommended approach for infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers is to receive both the hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG). The hepatitis B vaccine stimulates the baby's immune system to produce protective antibodies against the virus, while HBIG provides immediate passive immunity by providing pre-formed antibodies. This combined approach greatly reduces the risk of transmission.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hep B vaccine only: All infants, including those born to HBsAg-positive mothers, should receive the hepatitis B vaccine. However, in the case of HBsAg-positive mothers, additional intervention is needed.

Option C - First HBIG then Hep B after 1 month: This sequence is not the recommended approach. HBIG is given as soon as possible and the first dose of hep B vaccine is given within 7 days of exposure.

Option D - Only HBIG: Administering only HBIG without the hepatitis B vaccine is not sufficient for long-term protection against hepatitis B. The hepatitis B vaccine is essential for stimulating the baby's immune response and providing long-term immunity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker presents with pain in his right leg. Upon examination, the pulse in the bilateral popliteal fossa is absent, and he experiences pain in the both buttock . Which level block is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Aortoiliac Artery:

  • The patient's symptoms, including absent pulses in the bilateral popliteal fossa and pain in both buttocks, are indicative of aortoiliac artery disease.

  • Aortoiliac artery disease commonly presents with buttock, thigh, and calf claudication, which is pain or cramping in the muscles of the lower extremities during physical activity.

  • This condition is often associated with atherosclerosis, especially in chronic smokers like the patient described.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Femoral Artery Disease:

  • Common femoral artery disease typically presents with thigh and calf claudication, rather than pain in the buttocks.

  • In this condition, the patient may experience pain or cramping in the muscles of the thigh and calf during physical activity due to inadequate blood supply.

Option C - Popliteal Artery Disease:

  • Popliteal artery disease usually manifests as calf claudication, not pain in the buttocks.

  • Patients with popliteal artery disease may experience pain or cramping in the calf muscles during physical activity due to reduced blood flow to the lower leg.

Option D - Iliac Artery Disease:

  • While iliac artery disease can cause symptoms similar to aortoiliac artery disease, such as buttock, thigh, and calf claudication, the absent pulses in the bilateral popliteal fossa are not characteristic of isolated iliac artery disease.

questions.text: Keshan's disease is caused by a lack of
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Selenium

  • Keshan's disease is a condition characterized by the inflammation of the heart muscle (myocarditis), primarily affecting children and young women. It was first identified in Keshan County, China, hence the name.
  • The main cause of Keshan's disease is believed to be a deficiency of selenium, an essential trace element. Selenium is an important component of several enzymes involved in antioxidant defense mechanisms and the maintenance of heart muscle function.
  • When selenium levels are low, the heart becomes more susceptible to damage from free radicals and viral infections. This can lead to myocarditis and subsequent heart failure, which are the hallmark features of Keshan's disease.

Incorrect choices:

Option B: Zinc: Zinc deficiency can lead to various health problems, but it is not directly associated with Keshan's disease. Zinc is involved in many physiological processes, including immune function, growth, and development.

Option C: Copper: Copper deficiency can cause a range of symptoms, including anemia and neurological abnormalities, but it is not implicated in the development of Keshan's disease. Copper is essential for the synthesis of hemoglobin and the functioning of several enzymes.

Option D: Iron: Iron deficiency is commonly associated with anemia, but it is not the cause of Keshan's disease. Iron is necessary for the production of hemoglobin, which carries oxygen in the blood.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are NOT transmitted by this vector?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chagas disease:

  • The given image is of a sandfly. They are known to transmit various diseases, primarily caused by protozoan parasites of the Leishmania genus. Leishmaniasis is the collective term for these diseases.
  • Chagas disease: Chagas disease, also known as American trypanosomiasis, is not transmitted by sandflies. It is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, which is primarily transmitted by triatomine bugs (also known as "kissing bugs").

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Kala azar (Visceral leishmaniasis): This is a severe form of leishmaniasis caused by the Leishmania donovani parasite. Sandflies, particularly species of the genus Phlebotomus, transmit the parasite.

Option B - Oriental sore (Cutaneous leishmaniasis): This is a localized form of leishmaniasis caused by various species of Leishmania parasites. Sandflies transmit the parasite during their blood-feeding.

Option D - Cutaneous leishmaniasis: Various species of Leishmania parasites can cause cutaneous leishmaniasis, and it is transmitted by sandflies during their blood meals.

questions.text: Which contraceptive method should not be used in cases of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: OCP

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a condition characterized by the formation of blood clots in deep veins, usually in the legs. Certain contraceptives can increase the risk of developing DVT. These contraceptives contain hormones, such as estrogen and progestin, which can affect blood coagulation and increase the risk of blood clot formation.

Oral contraceptive pills (OCP): Oral contraceptive pills contain hormones, including estrogen and progestin. Estrogen, in particular, is associated with an increased risk of blood clot formation. Therefore, OCPs are contraindicated in individuals with a history of DVT or those at high risk of developing blood clots.

Contraindications of OCP:

  • Absolute:
    • Cancer of the breast and genitals
    • Liver disease
    • Previous or present history of thromboembolism
    • Cardiac abnormalities
    • Congenital hyperlipidaemia
    • Undiagnosed Abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Relative: (Special problems requiring medical surveillance)
    • Age over 40 years, or Smoking, and age over 35 years
      • Risk of cardiovascular ffects increases with age and smoking.
      • Go for progesterone-only pills.
      • If she is a smoker, don't give combined pills if her age is over 35 years.
    • Mild hypertension
    • Chronic renal disease
    • Epilepsy
    • Migraine
    • Nursing mothers in the first 6 months
    • Diabetes Mellitus
    • Gallbladder disease
    • History of infrequent bleeding
    • Amenorrhea, etc

Incorrect options:

Option A: IUD (Intrauterine device): The use of an IUD is not contraindicated in individuals with a history of DVT. IUDs do not contain hormones that affect blood coagulation.

Option B: Condoms: Condoms are a barrier method of contraception and do not contain hormones. They do not increase the risk of DVT.

Option D: No C/l (No contraindications): This option is incorrect because certain contraceptives, specifically those containing hormones, can indeed be contraindicated in individuals with a history of DVT or those at high risk.

questions.text: What are the absolute contraindications for intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs)?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Acute PID

  • Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) are a highly effective form of long-acting reversible contraception. While IUCDs are generally safe and well-tolerated, there are certain situations where they are contraindicated due to potential risks and complications.
  • Acute PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease): Acute PID is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of an IUCD. PID is an infection of the reproductive organs, and the presence of an IUCD can potentially worsen the infection, increase the risk of complications, and delay appropriate treatment.
Absolute Relative 
Pregnancy Anemia, Menorrhagia 
Recurrent PID History of PID 
Vaginal discharge of undiagnosed etiology  Purulent cervical discharge 
Cancer of cervix, uterus or adnexa  Distortion of uterine cavities e.g., congenital malformations, fibroids 
Previous ectopic pregnancy  Unmotivated person 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Anaemia: Anaemia is not an absolute contraindication for the use of an IUCD. It may be a relative contraindication if the anaemia is severe and associated with significant symptoms, but it does not pose a direct risk for IUCD insertion or use.

Option B: DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): DVT is not an absolute contraindication for IUCD use. DVT is primarily a concern with hormonal methods of contraception, such as combined oral contraceptives, due to the increased risk of blood clot formation. IUCDs, which do not contain hormones, do not have the same associated risk of DVT.

Option D: Endometriosis: Endometriosis is not an absolute contraindication for IUCD use. While it may cause symptoms and discomfort, it does not directly contraindicate the use of an IUCD. The choice of contraception in individuals with endometriosis may depend on various factors and should be discussed with a healthcare provider.

questions.text: The most suitable contraceptive recommendation for a recently married couple is:
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: OCPs

  • When providing contraceptive advice to a newly married couple, several factors need to be considered, including effectiveness, convenience, safety, and personal preferences. While the choice ultimately depends on the couple's specific needs and circumstances, oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are often a suitable option for many couples.
  • OCPs (Oral Contraceptive Pills): OCPs are a highly effective form of contraception when used correctly. They provide reliable pregnancy prevention, are convenient to use, and have additional benefits such as regulating menstrual cycles, reducing menstrual pain, and improving acne. OCPs can be started immediately and discontinued when the couple decides to conceive.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Condoms: Condoms are a barrier method of contraception that provide protection against both unintended pregnancies and sexually transmitted infections (STIs). They are easily accessible, affordable, and do not require a prescription. Condoms can be a good option for couples who prefer non-hormonal methods or need STI protection in addition to contraception. However, they may have a higher failure rate compared to hormonal methods like OCPs.

Option C: Sterilization: Sterilization, such as tubal ligation for women or vasectomy for men, is a permanent method of contraception. It is considered a long-term and highly effective option for couples who have completed their desired family size or do not wish to have biological children. Sterilization should be approached as a permanent decision, as reversal procedures are costly and not always successful.

Option D: IUD (Intrauterine Device): IUDs are long-acting reversible contraceptives that offer highly effective contraception for an extended period. They can be a suitable choice for couples who desire long-term contraception without the need for daily or frequent user involvement. However, IUDs require a healthcare provider's insertion, which may not be immediately accessible for a newly married couple.

questions.text: Identify the following condition
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Osteosarcoma:

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common type of cancer occurring in long bones and it’s common amongst children in 2nd decade. It is a metaphyseal tumor , usually located at Distal end of femur.  It has a bimodal presentation and is the most radioresistant tumor

  • Charecterstics: Codman triangle as seen in image (from elevation of periosteum) or sunburst pattern on x-ray (think of an osteocod [bone fish] swimming in the sun).

  • Treatment ; Neoadjuvent chemotherapy followed by surgery/ limb ablation

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ewing Sarcoma: Although Ewing sarcoma is also a bone-mediated tumor, it commonly affects pelvis, ribs, spine and long bones as opposed to Osteosarcoma which only affects the long bones of the arms and legs and the x–ray image is of the femur proving it to be the wrong answer.

Option C - Osteiod Osteoma: In case of Osteiod Osteoma the x-ray imaging shows presence of nidus surrounded by sclerosis, which is not indicating the x-ray image in the question. Hence it’s a wrong choice.

Option D - GCT: GCT, i.e., Giant Cell Tumors are typically found at the ends of the long bones and extend into the epiphysis to surface of the joint, whereas the images show a tumor which is not located at the end of the bone, hence this is a wrong choice.

questions.text: A Post-menopausal women slipped and fell down on an outstretched hand in the washroom.  X-ray of her distal forearm is given below. Diagnose the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Colle's Fracture:

  • Postmenopausal women are prone to develop osteoporosis due to decreased secretion of estrogen from ovaries. Women suffering from osteoporosis are prone to Colles fracture, which is a type of wrist fracture. This type of fracture usually happens after falling on an outstretched hand. The given x-ray shows fracture of the distal end of radius at cortico- cancellous junction, hence, Colles fracture is the correct choice.

Fracture Name

Characteristic Findings

Sites Involved

Special History

Colles' Fracture

Dorsal displacement of the distal radius

Distal radius

Falling on an outstretched hand

Smith's Fracture

Volar displacement of the distal radius

Distal radius

Falling on a flexed wrist

Monteggia Fracture

Proximal ulnar shaft fracture with radial head dislocation

Proximal ulna, radial head

Direct blow to the ulna or forearm

Galeazzi Fracture

Distal radial shaft fracture with distal radioulnar joint dislocation

Distal radius, radioulnar joint

Fall on an outstretched hand with an ulnar deviation

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Montaggiea fracture: The Monteggia fracture is the fracture of proximal ulna, which is associated with radial head dislocation. The given radiograph is indicating a distal radial fracture, hence it’s not a Monteggia fracture.

Option C - Smith Fracture: The image is not indication towards Smith fracture because volar angulation is the characteristic of Smith fracture, whereas the x-ray image is showing a dorsal angulation which is a characteristic of Colles fracture.

Option D - Galeazzi fracture: Galeazzi fracture, is the fracture of the middle of the distal third of the radius whereas the radiograph is showing a distal radial fracture hence it’s not the Galeazzi fracture.

questions.text: Identify the shown image
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Patella Tendon Bearing Brace:

  • A patella tendon bearing brace, also known as a patellar tendon brace or patellar tendon strap, is a specialized brace designed to provide targeted support and compression to the patellar tendon. It is commonly used in conditions such as patellar tendonitis or jumper's knee, where there is pain or inflammation in the patellar tendon.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ankle Knee Stabilizer: An ankle knee stabilizer is a type of brace or support that provides stability to both the ankle and knee joints. It is commonly used in cases of ligament injuries or instability in these joints.

Option C - Thomas Splint: The Thomas splint is a specific type of splint used for immobilization and stabilization of the femur or thigh bone. It is commonly used in cases of fractures or dislocations of the femur.

Option D - None of the above: This option is incorrect

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Port Wine stain:

  • Port Wine Stain is a phenomenon seen in children. It is a kind of hemangioma. It is usually present at birth and later fades with age. But it does not disappear. A hemangioma is, in fact, a vascular birthmark.

Incorrect options:

Option C - Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection where the lesions are present in the form of dome-shaped pearly lesions.

Option D - Squamous cell carcinoma is the cancer of the skin's outer and middle layer squamous cells.

questions.text: The marked muscle is supplied by which nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Musculocutaneous nerve:

  • The muscle that is marked in the diagram is the biceps brachii.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given image

questions.text: At which vertebral level can the celiac vessel be observed in?

questions.text: What is the mid-arm circumference measurement for severe acute malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Correct option D: < 11.5 cm:

  • Mid Arm Circumference (MAC) / Mid Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) is the circumference of the right upper arm measured at the midpoint between the tip of the shoulder and the tip of the elbow (olecranon process and the acromium).
    • Red: < 11.5 cm = Severe acute malnutrition
    • Yellow: 11.5-12.5 cm = Under nourished
    • Green: >12.5 cm = Normal

Incorrect options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 14-year-old child who has short stature, widely placed nipples, and primary amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Turner syndrome

  • Turner syndrome, also known as 45,X or monosomy X, is a genetic condition that affects females. It occurs when one of the two X chromosomes is partially or completely missing. The syndrome can lead to a variety of physical and developmental features.

The symptoms mentioned in the question are characteristic of Turner syndrome:

  1. Short stature: Girls with Turner syndrome often experience growth failure and have shorter-than-average height.
  2. Nipples widely placed: One of the physical features commonly seen in Turner syndrome is a wide spacing between the nipples.
  3. Primary amenorrhea: Girls with Turner syndrome typically have delayed or absent puberty, leading to the absence of menstrual periods.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Down syndrome (trisomy 21): Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. It is characterized by distinct physical features, intellectual disability, and various health issues. However, the symptoms mentioned in the question, such as short stature, widely placed nipples, and primary amenorrhea, are not typical of Down syndrome. Therefore, Down syndrome is not the correct diagnosis in this case.

Option C: Edward syndrome (trisomy 18): Edward syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18. It is associated with multiple congenital abnormalities affecting various organ systems. However, the symptoms mentioned in the question, including short stature, widely placed nipples, and primary amenorrhea, are not specifically associated with Edward syndrome. Hence, Edward syndrome is not the correct diagnosis for the presented symptoms.

Option D: Patau syndrome (trisomy 13): Patau syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 13. It is characterized by severe developmental issues, multiple congenital abnormalities, and intellectual disability. However, the symptoms described in the question, such as short stature, widely placed nipples, and primary amenorrhea, are not typically associated with Patau syndrome. Therefore, Patau syndrome is not the correct diagnosis for the given symptoms.

questions.text: Identify the abnormal condition given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Testicular Torsion:

  • The given image in question is suggestive of testicular torsion.

  • Testicular torsion is a urological emergency characterized by the twisting of the spermatic cord, which results in the twisting of the testicle.

  • This condition leads to the disruption of blood supply to the testicle, causing severe pain, swelling, and potential damage to the testicular tissue

  • Testicular torsion requires immediate medical attention and surgical intervention to restore blood flow and prevent testicular loss.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hydrocele: Hydrocele refers to the accumulation of fluid within the sac that surrounds the testicle. It typically causes painless swelling of the scrotum but is unrelated to testicular torsion.

Option B - Varicocele: Varicocele is the enlargement of the veins within the scrotum. It often presents as a mass or swelling and is commonly described as a "bag of worms" sensation. While varicocele can cause discomfort or pain, it is not directly associated with testicular torsion.

Option C - Testicular atrophy: Testicular atrophy refers to the shrinking or reduction in size of the testicles. It can occur due to various reasons, such as hormonal imbalances, infections, or trauma. Testicular atrophy is not specific to testicular torsion but may occur as a consequence of prolonged or untreated torsion.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 3-month-old baby who has a fever and a respiratory rate of 70/min, but shows no signs of stridor, chest indrawing, or convulsions?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Pneumonia:

Signs

Classify as

Treatment

Presence of any general

danger sign

Severe pneumonia

Give 1 dose of injection ampicillin and gentamicin and refer urgently to hospital

Presence of either chest

indrawing and/or fast

breathing but no general

danger sign

Pneumonia
  • Start oral amoxicillin x 5 days
  • The child is sent home and assessed after 48 hours
  • If the child has improved continue the same treatment
  • If the child has worsened, refer to a higher center

No fast breathing, no chest

indrawing, no general

danger signs

No pneumonia: Cough or cold only

Home-based supportive care

Fast breathing:

  • < 2 months: > 60/ min
  • 2-12 months: > 50/ min
  • 1-5 years: > 40/ min

General danger signs:

  • Convulsions
  • Lethargy
  • Inability to drink or breastfeed
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Unconsciousness
  • Stridor in a calm child

 

  • In the question above, the 3-month-old child has no danger signs but has fast breathing, i.e., >60/min, hence the child has pneumonia.
  • The treatment for children with pneumonia is to administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send them home.

Incorrect Options -B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Long term diabetic patient with blisters, walked barefoot for a few miles on hot sand. He is presented with this clinical condition. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Necrotizing fasciitis

  • The probable diagnosis based on the given clinical condition where patient is diabetic and the image is suggestive of necrotizing fasciitis
  • The image suggestive of necrotizing fasciitis supports this diagnosis due to the presence of extensive tissue necrosis and involvement.
  • Necrotizing fasciitis: Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive soft tissue infection that involves the deep fascial layers, causing necrosis of the affected tissues.
  • It is characterized by severe pain, erythema (redness), swelling, blistering, and signs of systemic toxicity.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Diabetic foot: Diabetic foot refers to a range of foot complications that can occur in individuals with diabetes. While diabetic foot ulcers and infections are common, the given clinical scenario and the image provided are more indicative of a severe soft tissue infection like necrotizing fasciitis rather than a typical diabetic foot ulcer.

Option B: Burn: Burns are caused by thermal, chemical, electrical, or radiation injury. While walking barefoot on hot sand can result in burns, the clinical presentation and the image showing extensive tissue involvement, necrosis, and signs of infection are not consistent with a simple burn injury.

Option D: Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a common bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, warmth, swelling, and tenderness of the affected area. While cellulitis is a possibility in a diabetic patient who walked barefoot, the image provided with extensive tissue necrosis is more indicative of necrotizing fasciitis, which is a more severe and rapidly progressing infection.

questions.text: How many primary teeth does a 3-year-old child have?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 20:

  • An average child develops a full set of 20 primary teeth by age 3.
  • The primary teeth begin to shed between the ages of 6 and 7, and permanent teeth appear.
  • By age 21, the average person develops 32 teeth, 16 on the upper jaw and 16 on the lower jaw.
